attributes.title: Antecedents and consequences of social distancing
attributes.description: In this project, we aim to assess the antecedents and consequences of social distancing in light of the current coronavirus pandemic using a longitudinal study design.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Antecedents and consequences of social distancing

other.value:
While the first wave has been already collected April 6th 2020 (to attune to the speed of developments during the pandemic), the next three waves will follow biweekly (2, 2, 4 weeks apart). We therefore preregister only hypotheses on the longitudinal dynamics and not on cross-sectional effects in wave 1.

Questionnaires for wave 1 and wave 2 (the questionnaire will be kept the same for wave 3 and 4) are accessible on the OSF project page.

We plan to characterize the development of social contacts, mood, and risk perceptions by latent growth curves. However, since the development of events is rather uncertain, other methods like latent class analyses may be applied to further characterize typical dynamics within each construct.

We also assessed perceived risks of personal economic problems. This will be used as time-varying covariate. We expect that the risk perception on economic problems will increase the longer distancing measures are in place. Moreover, economic risk perception may increase the number of face-to-face contacts, as people may be more inclined to ignore public advise.

Furthermore, we assessed need to belong at wave 1. This may moderate effects of social contacts on loneliness and/or on depressive mood.

Effects will also be controlled for Big5, assessed at wave 1.

sample.value: We aimed for 500 participants at wave 1. After voluntary opt-outs and eliminating people by seriousness checks, 427 participants will be included in the analyses and approached for all three subsequent waves. Overall, we expect an attrition rate of about 50%.

analyses.value:
We will use a cross-lagged panel design with latent variables in a SEM to evaluate our main hypothesis regarding Depressive mood (by IMS) and offline vs. online contacts

Mood will be predicted by the number of online and offline face-to-face contacts, the hours persons used each mean of communication, and their interaction (number of persons x hours for online and offline contacts).

We will evaluate our secondary hypothesis by predicting the number of face-to-face contacts by coronavirus risk perception (combining emotional and rational risk perception).

Temporal trends of each construct will also be captured via RM-ANOVAs. More explorative evaluations of dynamics will use latent growth curve/ latent class models.

outliers.value:
After eliminating people by seriousness checks, captcha, and voluntary opt-outs, 427 participants will be included in the analyses and approached for the subsequent three waves. 
Inclusion of the participant will be determined for each wave separately. Data will be included, if the participant fully fills out the questionnaire of the specific wave and passes an attention check placed in the questionnaire each wave.
Generally, longitudinal analyses will only be conducted, if we collect sufficient data. If the number of participants falls below a threshold of 100 participants for one time point, the whole wave may be dropped.

Since all scales are capped, we will use all data regardless of outliers. Potential logically inconsistent answers may be corrected, where possible, and dropped, where impossible.

dependent.value: Depressive mood (IMS), Depressive status (PHQ-9), Loneliness (UCLA); In case PHQ-9 and UCLA show no changes, we will use them as constant control variables and concentrate on IMS.

conditions.value: None, this is a longitudinal study.

hypothesis.value:
We expect that social distancing (i.e., fewer face-to-face contacts) has a negative impact on mood across time, so that people will show more symptoms of depression and loneliness in self-isolation during the corona-crisis. Furthermore, we want to test to what an extent online-contacts may alleviate these negative effects and which type of communication is necessary to maintain a positive mood.

In addition, as a secondary hypothesis, we expect that elevated risk perception on coronavirus will decrease the number of face-to-face contacts and, in turn, social distancing will decrease risk perception across time.

attributes.title: Partners in Prostate Cancer
attributes.description: Impact and experiences of female partners of men living with and beyond prostate cancer: A scoping review

summary.value:
This is a scoping review which seeks to explore the various aspects of a female's life that are impacted as a result of her partners prostate cancer diagnosis and survival.
Context
This review will consider studies that explore the female perspective on prostate cancer and any impact on the female. It will include studies from countries in the western world (as defined by World Population Review). Studies from developing countries will not be included as health service provision and support is likely to vary considerably in such locations. 
Only studies published in English will be utilised due to the language proficiency of the reviewing team. 
Studies focusing on same-sex partners will be excluded as these are seen as raising concepts beyond the context of the current study.
Types of Sources
This scoping review will consider studies that focus on qualitative data including, but not limited to, designs such as phenomenology, grounded theory, ethnography, qualitative description, action research and feminist research.
Quantitative research studies both experimental and quasi-experimental study designs including randomized controlled trials, non-randomized controlled trials, before and after studies and interrupted time-series studies will be considered. In addition, analytical observational studies including prospective and retrospective cohort studies, case-control studies and analytical cross-sectional studies will be considered for inclusion. This review will also consider descriptive observational study designs including case series, individual case reports and descriptive cross-sectional studies for inclusion. 
In addition systematic reviews that meet the inclusion criteria will also be included to elicit the opinions and conclusions drawn by a range of authors. 
Text and opinion papers will also be considered for inclusion in this scoping review.

attributes.title: PSYC331
attributes.description: The purpose of the project is to analyze the effect of text color on word recall. Participants will be given a randomized set of fifteen words in different colors and asked to memorize as many as possible within a span of sixty seconds. Afterward, the participant will be asked to recall as many words as possible.

q2.value: If participants are given a randomized set of fifteen words in different colors and asked to memorize as many as possible within a span of sixty seconds, then participants will recall the most words in the treatment where black words are against a white background, as that is currently the most common method of presenting data.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Multi-Group Within-Subject Design. The independent variable (text color) has five levels. The design will be counterbalanced by random order treatments.

q8.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value: Data will be collected through Qualtrics. The survey will be sent to friends and colleagues with instructions on how to complete the survey along with a request to forward it further.

q11.value: There will be a minimum of fifteen participants with no limit to the number of maximum participants.

question.value: The five levels of the independent variable (text color) are: white text against a black background, red text against a white background, blue text against a white background, green text against a white background, and black text against a white background
The dependent variable will be measured by the number of words correctly recalled.
We will use a within-subjects ANOVA to analyze the results.

attributes.title: In the preparation and administration of intravenous medicines, what are the best practice standards that healthcare professionals need to follow to ensure patient safety?
attributes.description:
Abstract 

Introduction  

Intravenous therapy and medicines (IVTM) are the most common invasive interventions in use in healthcare. Prescribed IVTM play an essential role in the treatment of illness, management of chronic conditions and in maintaining health and wellbeing. The intravenous (IV) route is the administration of concentrated medications (diluted or undiluted) directly into peripherally or centrally inserted vascular access devices. Medication safety is a key priority and best practice standards are required to guide the safe preparation and administration of IVTM.  

Methods  

We will conduct a systematic review of the literature pertaining to the preparation and administration of intravenous therapy and medicines. Our search will include studies concerned with the preparation and/or administration of IVTM via peripheral or central vascular access devices. We will be guided by the preferred reporting items for systematic review and meta-analysis (PRISMA) in this review. Literature will include all trial designs, national/international guidelines, and expert consensus opinion made available in English from 2009 to present day. 

Conclusion  

We will synthesise the evidence concerning safe and effective preparation and administration of intravenous therapy and medicines to inform the development of a national guideline for healthcare professionals in Ireland. The availability of up-to-date, contemporaneous evidence-based practice standards will ensure quality and safety for service-users.

attributes.title: The relationships between team composition, team communication, and team performance and their cross-level influence on individual communication and performance
attributes.description: We empirically research the relationships between team characteristics, communication behaviour, and performance in teams. On the team level we analyse how team characteristics influence team communication and how this in turn influences team outcomes. On the individual level we investigate the relationship between individual characteristics and communication in a team setting and test whether team characteristics influence individual communication behaviour and if individual performance therefore systematically depends on those team characteristics.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: The relationships between team composition, team communication, and team performance and their cross-level influences on individual communication and performance

other.value: Data collection has been completed. Furthermore the coding of the video data has started. For a subsample of 30 teams, chosen at random, the first team task was coded and Hypotheses 7-9 were analysed in order to check whether a sample of 80 teams would be sufficient to find cross-level effects with multi-level modelling or further data collection was needed. No further analyses besides the ones mentioned above have been conducted.

sample.value: According to an a priori power analysis based on similar data, a sample size of 80 teams with 4 team members is sufficient to find expected effects. Data collection of 100 teams was planned to account for technical issues, participants retracting their participation for the study due to data confidentiality reasons, and other problems during data collection. The team assessment of the assessment center consists of four team tasks. Two tasks of the team assessment will be coded and analysed for all 80 teams. All four tasks of the team assessment will be coded and analysed for a subsample of 30 teams.

analyses.value:
Testing of the hypotheses will be performed with hierarchical linear regressions and hierarchical multilevel analysis. Mediated hierarchical linear regressions will be used to analyse the relationships at the team level while hierarchical multilevel analyses are a suitable choice to analyse the relationships at the individual level and situational factors and individual communication and performance.
Once we have progressed into the analysis phase, we might realize that other analyses are preferable and thus conduct those instead.

outliers.value: There is no theoretical reason to exclude outliers. We expect to be dealing with missings at random (MAR) or missings completely at random (MCAR). Data sets with missing values will be analysed if the missing values do not affect the applied method directly, otherwise data will be discarded from further analysis.

dependent.value:
Communication data is collected during the team assessment of an assessment center. Team interaction is filmed and coded by two trained coders using the act4teams coding scheme and Mangold Interact coding software.
For performance measures at the individual level, the achieved individual scores during the tasks as well as the assessors’ ratings of performance are used. Team performance is based on the progress of the team tasks for problem solving tasks and whether agreement was reached for the decision making tasks.

conditions.value: All subjects participate in four different tasks during the team assessment. Two of these tasks are problem solving tasks and two of them are decision making tasks. For all subjects one problem solving task and one decision making task will be analysed. For a subsample all four tasks will be used for analysis (see below). This correlational study does not contain any experimental conditions.

hypothesis.value:
Research Question:
We empirically research the relationships between team characteristics, communication behaviour, and performance in teams. On the team level we analyse how team characteristics influence team communication and how this in turn influences team outcomes. On the individual level we investigate the relationship between individual characteristics and communication in a team setting and test whether team characteristics influence individual communication behaviour and if individual performance therefore systematically depends on those team characteristics.

Hypotheses:
Team level
Team levels of Agreeableness, Conscientiousness and Extraversion are expected to relate positively to team cooperation, task focused communication and distributed communication participation respectively which in turn are expected to relate positively to team performance (Hypotheses 1-3). Team extraversion is also expected to be positively related to task irrelevant communication and communication disruptions which are expected to be negatively related to team performance (Hypothesis 4).
Team performance is furthermore expected to be higher in teams in which high team levels of the traits Agreeableness and Conscientiousness are a result of at least one individual being high in both traits as opposed to the high trait levels being distributed amongst all members (Hypothesis 5).
Team efficacy is expected to be positively related to prosocial behaviour and consequently team performance (Hypothesis 6).

Individual level
In line with relationships on the team level, individual levels of Agreeableness, Conscientiousness, and Extraversion are expected to relate positively to individual cooperation, task focused communication and communication duration respectively (Hypotheses 7-9).
Self-efficacy is expected to have a positive relationship with cooperation and coordinative communication behaviour and hence individual performance (Hypothesis 10).

Cross-level influence of team the team level onto the individual level
Team levels of Agreeableness, Conscientiousness, and Extraversion are expected to have a positive cross-level impact on the expression of the respective trait on the individual level (Hypotheses 11-13). Variance in team Agreeableness, team Conscientiousness, and team Extraversion, in other words team heterogeneity of these traits, are expected to have a negative impact on the expression of the same traits on the individual level (Hypotheses 14-16).
Team efficacy is expected to have a positive cross level effect on the expression of cooperation and coordinative communication behaviour on the individual level (Hypothesis 17).

attributes.title: The neurobiology of paternal protection
attributes.description: The current project aims to explore the neurobiological correlates of paternal protection by combining behavioral measurements, neural responses and hormonal levels.
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

additionalComments.value:
For the current paper, the data collection is completed. Preprocessing of the fMRI data and AST is completed. None of the confirmatory or exploratory analyses have been performed yet.

question10b.value:
Procedure 
Participants were invited for three assessments, with the pretest approximately 8-17 weeks after birth, the posttest approximately 12-21 weeks after birth, and a follow-up around 29-45 weeks post-birth. The first two research visits were located either in the Leiden University Medical Centre (LUMC) or at the participant’s home, depending on possible MRI contra-indications (i.e. diabetes, neurological diagnosis, metallic foreign objects in participant’s body) and preference of the participant. Between the pretest and posttest, participants received an instruction about the intervention and were asked to use the assigned baby tool, either a baby seat or a baby carrier, for three weeks, for a minimal of six hours per week divided over at least four days. Between the post-test and follow-up, participants could keep the assigned tool and use it as often as they preferred. The study is approved by the Ethics Committees of the Leiden University Medical Centre and of the Department of Education and Child studies at Leiden University. All participants gave informed consent. For the current paper, we focus on the pretest assessment.

The pretest assessment consisted of at least three parts: 1. Behavioral measurements, including a 10 minute Free play (Witte, De Moor, Van Ijzendoorn, & Bakermans-Kranenburg, 2019), the Auditory Startling Task (AST, Witte et al., 2019), a handgrip force paradigm (Alyousefi-Van Dijk et al., 2019), and the Five Minute Speech Sample (Lotz et al., 2020); 2. Saliva and hair sampling for hormonal measurements; and 3. Questionnaires about e.g. health, medication and current mental state. When the assessment took place in the LUMC, additional neural measurements were taken with (f)MRI and DTI. Following the assessment, participants and partners completed some online questionnaires at home (including the Parental Protection Questionnaire; See Van ’t Veer et al., 2019). 


Measures
Auditory Startling task .To observe paternal protective behavior, we applied the Auditory Startling Task (Witte et al., 2019). During the AST, a loud short sound fragment was played “unexpectedly” by a hidden audio installation while the participant was playing with his infant. Participant and infant were playing alone in a separate room while being videotaped. The sound consisted of white noise (80-db) and was programmed for 10 seconds with short breaks. At the end of the sound fragment, the researcher entered the room and apologized for the sound: e.g. ‘I am sorry for the sound, we had some technical problems’. The purpose of the sound fragment was explained to the participants at the end of the follow-up visit. 
Protective behavior of the participant towards the infant in reaction to the sound fragment, and baby states before and during the sound fragment were coded from the video. The baby state before the sound fragment was coded based on observation of the 30 seconds before the start of the white noise. The baby state during the sound fragment was also coded. Coding of the protective behavior in reaction to the white noise was stopped when the researcher entered the room.

The coding manual was developed for the current study. Two authors (MBK & AL) watched 10 AST videos and listed the observed protective responses and added other possible protective behaviors in reaction to the auditory stimuli. Subsequently, 10 members of the research team, including MBK and AL, rated these behaviors on protective behavior (1= least protective; 8= most protective). A correlation matrix of these ratings revealed that all r > .80, indicating that in general all raters agreed on rating order. The final coding scheme consists of a 10-point scale, with higher scores reflecting more protective behavior, see Table 1 for an overview. The coding scheme for baby states before and during noise was adapted from Mah, Bakermans-Kranenburg, Van Ijzendoorn, & Smith (2015) and consists of a 5-point scale: 1. Drowsy or asleep, 2. Quiet, 3. Alert, 4. Startled, 5. Fussing, 6. Distressed. When various states or responses were observed, the highest rating corresponding to these responses was assigned
Five raters were trained by one of the authors (AL). Interrater reliability was assessed based on a total of 20 videos. A first set of ten videos was scored directly after the training. A second set of ten videos was coded after all raters coded several videos independently. All raters obtained good inter rater reliability (Single measures absolute agreement, Parental protection ICC > .84, Baby state before noise ICC > .67, Baby state during noise ICC > .75). 

fMRI protection task. To examine the possible neural basis for paternal protection, fathers participated in an fMRI task that was adapted from Van ‘t Veer et al. (2019). In the current protection task, as described in Witte et al. (2019), participants watched videos while lying in an MRI scanner. The videos depicted either a scenario in which an infant was in a threatening situation, or a matched neutral video in which there was no threat to the infant. During the task, participants watched 12 different video pairs (see table 2. for a description of the videos). The videos (that will be made available upon request) were filmed using a gender-neutral lifelike baby doll. Fathers were instructed to imagine that the infant in the videos was their own infant. To ease the task of imagining their own infant in the videos, a picture of their infant was shown during the task. Moreover, the presentation of the doll’s face and the faces of the actors in the videos was minimized.
Each video, 12 threatening videos and 12 matched neutral videos, was shown twice to each participant, resulting in a total of 48 videos. The duration of each video was 6 seconds. The videos were shown in one of four pre-programmed semi-random orders. The order was selected based on participant identification number (1 assigned to order 1, 4 to order 4, 5 to order 1, etc.). For each order, it was ensured that videos were equally distributed across the task: 12 neutral and 12 threatening videos were presented during the first half of the task as well as the second half of the task. To maximize the power of the design, inter stimulus interval (ISI) between videos was sampled using the web-based tool Neurodesign (Durnez, Blair, & Poldrack, 2017). Videos were separated by an ISI of variable length ranging from 3.0 – 8.0 seconds, with a mean ISI of 4.5 seconds. The task was programmed in E-Prime software (version 2.0; Psychology Software Tools, Inc., PA, USA).

Prior to the first assessment, participants were asked to send a picture of their own child. Each photo was edited in Adobe Photoshop CS by adding a black-face contour to remove ears and most of the hair, and a black background. To ensure that all images contain approximately the same pixel ratio between the black background and face, images were resized so that face length was set on 10 cm. Finally, a selection of the picture containing the face was copied to a new black image of 640*480 pixels. Participants were familiarized to the edited image and task design during a practice task prior to the MRI scan session, while viewing videos that were not included in the real task. At the onset of the real task, an edited picture of participants own infant was shown with a written instruction to imagine that their own infant is displayed in the succeeding videos. The instruction and edited picture were shown again after each eight videos (thus six times in total). After a stimulus interval of 250 milliseconds, the instruction screen advanced to one of the four pre-programmed semi-random order of 48 videos as described above. 

fMRI parameters. MRI scanning was performed on a 3 T Philips Achieva TXMRI system (Philips Medical Systems, Best, the Netherlands). For registration purposes, a T1-weighted anatomical scan was acquired (repetition time (TR)= 7.90 ms, echo time (TE) =  3.50 ms, flip angle = 8°, 155 transverse slices, ACQ voxel size 1.1 × 1.1 × 1.1 mm). The fMRI-task utilized a gradient-echo blood oxygen level dependent (BOLD) echo-planar imaging sequence with: TR = 2200 ms, TE = 30 ms, flip angle = 80°, 38 transverse slices, and ACQ voxel size of 2.75 × 2.75 × 2.75 mm (including a default interslice gap). The duration of the fMRI paradigm was 10 min 53 s (290 volumes). Fieldmap corrections were performed using a multi-acquisition B0 map, performed directly after the end of the fMRI protection task. 

Parental Protection Questionnaire. To measure father’s protective behavior towards the child in daily life, fathers and partners were asked to fill in the Parental Protection Questionnaire (PPQ, see Van ‘t Veer et al. (2019) for a prenatal version of this questionnaire) after each assessment. The partners reported on the participants’ protective behavior as well. The current questionnaire contains 12 items that had to be scored on the prevalence during the past month (1= never, 2= seldom, 3= sometimes, 4= often or always, 5= not applicable). Examples of questions are: ‘I made sure that the baby’s diaper was changed in time’, or ‘I made sure that the living room was safe for the baby’. Using an exploratory factor analysis on participants’ data, items loading >.40 on the factor explaining the most of the variance will be selected to calculate the mean score for both participant and partner.

Salivary vasopressin/testosterone. Salivary samples were obtained at the beginning of each assessment. Participants were instructed not to consume any alcoholic drinks or have excessive physical exercise during the last 24 hours prior to each assessment. Furthermore, participants were asked not to drink any caffeine containing drinks on the day of the assessment, and not to smoke, chew gum, eat or drink (except for water) 30 minutes before the start of the appointment. Just before sampling participants rinsed their mouth with water. All samples were stored as soon as possible at -20 ˚C. Saliva collected at home were placed on ice for transportation. 

Testosterone. Participants drool approximately 1.5 ml saliva into a 2 ml cryogenic vial (SalivaBio, Salimetrics), either directly into the vial or indirectly using a saliva collection aid (Saliva Bio, Salimetrics). Before drooling, participants were asked to swallow once and to slightly bent forward. To stimulate saliva production, participants were recommended to think about something sweet or sour, to move their jaws up and down, or to look at pictures of food that were provided. Testosterone was quantified at Dresden LabService GmbH (Germany) by Luminscence enzyme immunoassay (IBL International GMBH). Fifty µL of each sample was used for the immunoassay. The limit of detection was 1.8 pg/mL. Samples used for the current article were quantified in the same assay run (12 plates in total). Duplicate analyses was performed for a random selection of 30% of the samples. Inter-assay variability was 10% and intra-assay variability was 5.22%. Cross-reactivity with other substances tested < 0.01 %.

Vasopressin. Participants chewed on a cotton swab (Salivette, Sarstedt) for 60 seconds. Saliva for the quantification of OT and AVP was collected using salivettes (Sarstedt). Participants were instructed to chew lightly on a cotton swab for 60 seconds and move the swab around in their mouth every now and then to boost saliva collection. Researchers kept track of the time using a stopwatch. Oxytocin and vasopressin were quantified by radioimunnoassay at RIAgnosis (Sinzing, Germany). Salivettes were centrifuged at 4 degrees Celsius for 30 minutes with ca. 5000 g centrifugal force, after which 0.6 ml of saliva was pipetted into a vial (0.3 ml for the analysis of OT and 0.3 ml for the analysis of AVP). Both for OT and AVP and the detection limit was 0.1 pg/ml. All pre-test samples were analyzed simultaneously in the same assay run. Intra-assay variability was < 10%. There is no significant cross-reactivity with other neuropeptides (< 0.7%).

question4b.value: In order to be eligible to participate in this study, subjects must meet all of the following criteria: 1. Fathers who have had their first baby, male adults in the early postnatal phase of parenthood (child’s age = +/-2 month). 2. The baby is a full-term, healthy infant.

question5b.value: Data were collected during research visits at the Leiden University Medical Center (LUMC) and/or at the participant’s home. If the participant was eligible to undergo a MRI scan, the fMRI and AST data were collected during a research visit at the LUMC. AST data were never collected at participant’s home. Baseline salivary hormones were either collected at the LUMC or at home, depending where the research visit took place. The Parental Protection Questionnaire (PPQ) was always filled in at home by both the participant and his partner. The procedure of the data collection is described below.

question6b.value: The obtained sample size is 78 participants. A meta-analysis on the association between parenting behavior and T levels in fathers showed a combined effect size of Hedges’ g = 0.14, equivalent to r = .07 (Meijer et al., 2019). With our sample size, a combined effect size of r = .07 results in a power of .09 (at an alpha level of .05). However, the meta-analysis included studies with a broad range of parenting-related measures, and their relevance to parental protection is unclear. Hardly any study on protective parenting is available. It is thus difficult to estimate the power achieved with our sample size accurately. When taking into account the only effect size related to protective parenting (r = .46, Alyousefi- Van Dijk et al., 2019), power would be > .90, but this was a study with a small sample size and the confidence interval (CI) of the effect size is (.08, .72). We can, as an alternative, determine what effect sizes we can detect in our sample. This is necessary for those associations between neural, behavioral and hormonal measurements for which no effect sizes can be derived from the literature, and thus are more exploratory. Therefore, we computed what effects we can detect as significant with our sample. Power value was set at .80, alpha at .05, resulting in detectable effect sizes of r = .31. This effect size is larger than what we consider the smallest effect size of interest (SESOI, Lakens, Scheel, & Isager, 2018). We suggest that effect sizes r ≥ .08 are of interest for further study and replication, as this is the lower end of the CI around the effect size of the aforementioned study (determination of SESOI as suggested by Perugini, Gallucci, & Costantini, 2014, although ideally this should be based on the CI of a meta-analytic effect size of pertinent studies).

question7b.value: The inclusion of participants was ended half December 2019. Participants had to be able to come for the first assessment before the end of January 2020.

question6c.value: To control for multiple testing, a Benjamini-Hochberg correction will be applied.

question7c.value: Missing data will be imputed via Multiple Imputation with the R package ‘mice’ (Van Buuren & Groothuis-Oudshoorn, 2011). For the construction of the imputation model, all variables included in the exploratory and confirmatory analyses and auxiliary variables were taken into account. Selected auxiliary variables are age of the infant at time of the first assessment, start time of the first assessment, scored baby state before AST noise. The multiply imputed data will be pooled in the confirmatory and the exploratory analyses.

question8c.value: Parental Protection Questionnaire: Exploratory Factor Analysis will be performed to determine how many underlying factors are present in the questionnaire data. Items loading on eigenvalue >.40 on the factor explaining the most of the variance will be selected. A Cronbach’s alpha will be calculated to assess the internal consistency of these selected items.

question10c.value: Confirmatory and exploratory correlational analyses: All data will be checked for parametric assumptions. If met, Pearson correlations will be calculated between each measure. If not met, data will be transformed to achieve or approach a normal distribution. When the transformation does not result in a normal distribution, Spearman correlations will be performed in sensitivity analyses. Significance will be set on p < .05.

question1a.value:
The current study aims to explore the neurobiological correlates of paternal protection. 
1.	We hypothesize that the different indicators of paternal protection (protective behavior, neural responses to infant threat, and testosterone and vasopressin levels) are positively related to each other (Figure 1.): 
a.	Based on expected construct validity, we expect a significant positive relation between observed and reported protective behavior. 
b.	Based on previous literature, we expect a positive association between baseline testosterone (T) and vasopressin (AVP) levels and neural reactivity to threatening stimuli in brain areas involved the parental care network, visual processing areas and threat detection. 
c.	Based on previous literature, we expect a positive association between baseline T and AVP levels and protective behavior. 
d.	Based on previous literature, we expect a positive association between protective behavior and neural reactivity to threatening stimuli in brain areas involved in the parental care network, visual processing areas and threat detection.
2.	Based on the biological interaction between hormones and the brain, it is speculated that the relation between salivary hormone levels and protective behavior is mediated by neural responses in brain areas involved in the parental care network, visual processing areas and threat detection (Figure 2.). We expect that higher basal T and AVP levels are related to higher protective parenting, when increased neural reactivity is observed.

question3a.value:
-	Neuro-imaging data: threatening videos result in a significant different neural response compared to neutral videos. 
-	Observed protective behavior: a sudden loud sound is present during father-infant interaction.

question5a.value:
An important aspect of parental care, however largely neglected in parenting research, is infant protection (Bakermans-Kranenburg & Van IJzendoorn, 2017). Parental protective behavior may be important for the promotion of secure attachment. Specifically, experiences with protective parents may enhance children’s trust in parent’s availability to help and protect them in times of danger or distress (Bowbly, 1982). Since most research on protective parenting concentrated on mothers (Hahn-Holbrook, Holbrook, & Haselton, 2011), the current study aims to address the psychobiology of protective behavior in fathers. 
Paternal protective behavior has been studied in a variety of contexts, however, to our knowledge, only few studies combined behavioral, neural or endocrine aspects to address the psychobiology of paternal behavior. For example, males’ behavioral and neural responses have been studied during exposure to infant crying, an indicator for a possible threatening situation (e.g. Alyousefi-Van Dijk et al., 2019; Li, Chen, Mascaro, Haroon, & Rilling, 2017; Thijssen et al., 2018; Van Anders, Tolman, & Volling, 2012). Furthermore, fathers’ protective behavior and neural responses towards the (unborn) child in daily life situations have been studied (e.g. Van ’t Veer, Thijssen, Witteman, Van IJzendoorn, & Bakermans-Kranenburg, 2019). Moreover, several literature reviews concluded that paternal behavior has a possible neuro-endocrine basis (Abraham & Feldman, 2018; Hahn-Holbrook et al., 2011; Rilling & Mascaro, 2017), indicating that paternal hormones, such as testosterone and vasopressin, and specific neural activation might be proper correlates or even activators of observed protective behavior. 

The possible role of testosterone and vasopressin in protective parenting has been incorporated in the Steroid/Peptide Model of Social Bonds by Van Anders, Goldey, & Kuo (2011). Firstly, their model implies that low levels of testosterone might be linked to parental contexts that are perceived as nurturing. This statement is in line with previous research showing that lower salivary testosterone is associated with increased participation of fathers in child care and enhanced quality of caregiving, both prenatally (Bos et al., 2018; Edelstein et al., 2017) and postnatally (Bos et al., 2018; Gettler, McDade, Feranil, & Kuzawa, 2011; Weisman, Zagoory-Sharon, & Feldman, 2014), although combined effect sizes are small (for meta-analysis see Meijer, Van IJzendoorn, & Bakermans - Kranenburg, 2019). Additionally, the model of Van Anders and colleagues implies that high levels of testosterone are associated with parental contexts that involve a need for protective responses. Indeed, it was shown that testosterone administration increased males’ neural responses to facial threat cues in brain areas associated with threat processing (Goetz et al., 2014) and that cry sounds increased salivary testosterone levels in men when no nurturing action was possible (Van Anders et al., 2012). Based on these findings, we expect a positive association between baseline testosterone levels, protective behavior and neural reactivity to threatening stimuli. 
Secondly, the Steroid/Peptide Model states a specific role for AVP reactivity in protective parenting, namely that protective aggression is positively related to increases of AVP (Van Anders et al., 2011). A number of studies suggest that paternal protection might be associated with AVP. For instance, administration of AVP increased father-to-be’s orientation towards baby avatars (Cohen-Bendahan, Beijers, Van Doornen, & de Weerth, 2015) and it affected the neural processing of emotionally labeled infant cry sounds (Thijssen et al., 2018). Moreover, basal AVP levels in fathers have been shown to be negatively related to brain activity in brain areas involved in empathy and social cognition when viewing neutral or positive videos of own infant vs other infant. The authors interpreted this as a possible AVP-dependent vigilance to strangers (Atzil, Hendler, Zagoory-Sharon, Winetraub, & Feldman, 2012). In contrast, other studies showed that AVP administration did not increase handgrip force in reaction to infant crying in first time expectant fathers (Alyousefi-Van Dijk et al., 2019) or fathers’ neural processing of infant cry and the subjective cry rating (Li et al., 2017), and no correlation between basal AVP levels and explicit and implicit infant caregiving was observed in prospective fathers (Cohen-Bendahan et al., 2015). Thus, mixed findings are present for the role of AVP, both for basal and reactive hormone levels, in protective behavior. However, no studies to date specifically looked at AVP in relation to protective paternal behavior and neural processing of infant threat. Based on previous findings and the theory of the Steroid/Peptide Model, we predict that basal levels of AVP are associated with more protective behavior and stronger neural responses to infant threat. 

	To our knowledge, few studies have focused on the relation between protective behavior and its neural correlates. An fMRI study with fathers focusing on dangerous daily situations revealed that several brain networks known to be associated with the parental care network, visual processing areas and threat detection, are involved in processing of videos depicting infant threatening situations (Van ’t Veer et al., 2019). Moreover, Van ‘t Veer and colleagues observed that protective behavior in daily life was linked to stronger brain activation while watching their own (versus an unknown) infant in threatening (versus neutral) situations. Based on these findings, we hypothesize a neural threat component that will be positively associated with observed and reported protective behavior.

Preprocessing of AST
It will be checked whether data for the three scales (protective response, baby state before noise and baby state during noise) is normally distributed and whether outliers are present in the data. When needed data will be transformed to achieve a normal distribution. 


Preprocessing of baseline hormone levels
It will be checked whether the data is normally distributed and whether outliers are present in the data. When needed, data will be transformed to achieve a normal distribution.


Preprocessing PPQ
PPQ – step 1. Participants’ responses - the validation of the questionnaire:
Exploratory Factor Analysis will be performed to determine how many underlying factors are present in the questionnaire data. Items loading on eigenvalue >.4 will be selected. A Cronbach’s alpha will be calculated to assess the internal consistency of these selected items. Based on the selected items, a mean score will be calculated.

PPQ – step 2. Partners’ responses: 
Items selected based in step 1 are selected from the partners questionnaires. A Cronbach’s alpha will be calculated to assess the internal consistency for these items. Based on the selected items, a mean score will be calculated. 


Preprocessing fMRI
fMRI – step 1. Data is structured following the Brain Imaging Data Structure (BIDS). Firstly, Dicom scans collected during the fMRI protection task were converted to .nifti and .json files via the dcm2niix converter. Subsequently, the .nifti files and corresponding stimulus data were checked via the BIDS validator. 

fMRI – step 2. Preprocessing is performed using fMRIPrep (version ≥1.5.2 (Esteban, Markiewicz, et al. (2018); Esteban, Blair, et al. (2018); RRID:SCR_016216)), which is based on Nipype 1.3.1 (Gorgolewski et al. (2011); Gorgolewski et al. (2018); RRID:SCR_002502).
Anatomical data preprocessing. T1-weighted (T1w) images were corrected for intensity non-uniformity (INU) with N4BiasFieldCorrection,(Tustison et al. 2010), distributed with ANTs 2.2.0 (Avants et al. 2008, RRID:SCR_004757). The T1w-reference was then skull-stripped with Nipype implementation of the antsBrainExtraction.sh workflow (from ANTs), using OASIS30ANTs as target template. Brain tissue segmentation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), white-matter (WM) and gray-matter (GM) was performed on the brain-extracted T1w using fast (FSL 5.0.9, RRID:SCR_002823, Zhang, Brady, and Smith 2001). A T1w-reference map was computed after registration of T1w images (after INU-correction) using mri_robust_template (FreeSurfer 6.0.1, Reuter, Rosas, and Fischl 2010). Brain surfaces were reconstructed using recon-all (FreeSurfer 6.0.1, RRID:SCR_001847, Dale, Fischl, and Sereno 1999), and the brain mask estimated previously was refined with a custom variation of the method to reconcile ANTs-derived and FreeSurfer-derived segmentations of the cortical gray-matter of Mindboggle (RRID:SCR_002438, Klein et al. 2017). Volume-based spatial normalization to two standard spaces (MNI152NLin2009cAsym, MNI152NLin6Asym) was performed through nonlinear registration with antsRegistration (ANTs 2.2.0), using brain-extracted versions of both T1w reference and the T1w template. The following templates were selected for spatial normalization: ICBM 152 Nonlinear Asymmetrical template version 2009c [Fonov et al. (2009), RRID:SCR_008796; TemplateFlow ID: MNI152NLin2009cAsym], FSL’s MNI ICBM 152 non-linear 6th Generation Asymmetric Average Brain Stereotaxic Registration Model [Evans et al. (2012), RRID:SCR_002823; TemplateFlow ID: MNI152NLin6Asym].
Functional data preprocessing. For each BOLD run, the following preprocessing was performed. First, a reference volume and its skull-stripped version were generated using a custom methodology of fMRIPrep. A deformation field to correct for susceptibility distortions was estimated based on fMRIPrep’s fieldmap-less approach. The deformation field is that resulting from co-registering the BOLD reference to the same-subject T1w-reference with its intensity inverted (Wang et al. 2017; Huntenburg 2014). Registration is performed with antsRegistration (ANTs 2.2.0), and the process regularized by constraining deformation to be nonzero only along the phase-encoding direction, and modulated with an average fieldmap template (Treiber et al. 2016). Based on the estimated susceptibility distortion, an unwarped BOLD reference was calculated for a more accurate co-registration with the anatomical reference. The BOLD reference was then co-registered to the T1w reference using bbregister (FreeSurfer) which implements boundary-based registration (Greve and Fischl 2009). Co-registration was configured with six degrees of freedom. Head-motion parameters with respect to the BOLD reference (transformation matrices, and six corresponding rotation and translation parameters) are estimated before any spatiotemporal filtering using mcflirt (FSL 5.0.9, Jenkinson et al. 2002). BOLD runs were slice-time corrected using 3dTshift from AFNI 20160207 (Cox and Hyde 1997, RRID:SCR_005927). The BOLD time-series, were resampled to surfaces on the following spaces: fsaverage6. The BOLD time-series (including slice-timing correction when applied) were resampled onto their original, native space by applying a single, composite transform to correct for head-motion and susceptibility distortions. These resampled BOLD time-series will be referred to as preprocessed BOLD in original space, or just preprocessed BOLD. The BOLD time-series were resampled into several standard spaces, correspondingly generating the following spatially-normalized, preprocessed BOLD runs: MNI152NLin2009cAsym, MNI152NLin6Asym. First, a reference volume and its skull-stripped version were generated using a custom methodology of fMRIPrep. Automatic removal of motion artifacts using independent component analysis (ICA-AROMA, Pruim et al. 2015) was performed on the preprocessed BOLD on MNI space time-series after removal of non-steady state volumes and spatial smoothing with an isotropic, Gaussian kernel of 6mm FWHM (full-width half-maximum). Corresponding “non-aggresively” denoised runs were produced after such smoothing. Additionally, the “aggressive” noise-regressors were collected and placed in the corresponding confounds file. Several confounding time-series were calculated based on the preprocessed BOLD: framewise displacement (FD), DVARS and three region-wise global signals. FD and DVARS are calculated for each functional run, both using their implementations in Nipype (following the definitions by Power et al. 2014). The three global signals are extracted within the CSF, the WM, and the whole-brain masks. Additionally, a set of physiological regressors were extracted to allow for component-based noise correction (CompCor, Behzadi et al. 2007). Principal components are estimated after high-pass filtering the preprocessed BOLD time-series (using a discrete cosine filter with 128s cut-off) for the two CompCor variants: temporal (tCompCor) and anatomical (aCompCor). tCompCor components are then calculated from the top 5% variable voxels within a mask covering the subcortical regions. This subcortical mask is obtained by heavily eroding the brain mask, which ensures it does not include cortical GM regions. For aCompCor, components are calculated within the intersection of the aforementioned mask and the union of CSF and WM masks calculated in T1w space, after their projection to the native space of each functional run (using the inverse BOLD-to-T1w transformation). Components are also calculated separately within the WM and CSF masks. For each CompCor decomposition, the k components with the largest singular values are retained, such that the retained components’ time series are sufficient to explain 50 percent of variance across the nuisance mask (CSF, WM, combined, or temporal). The remaining components are dropped from consideration. The head-motion estimates calculated in the correction step were also placed within the corresponding confounds file. The confound time series derived from head motion estimates and global signals were expanded with the inclusion of temporal derivatives and quadratic terms for each (Satterthwaite et al. 2013). Frames that exceeded a threshold of 0.5 mm FD or 1.5 standardised DVARS were annotated as motion outliers. All resamplings can be performed with a single interpolation step by composing all the pertinent transformations (i.e. head-motion transform matrices, susceptibility distortion correction when available, and co-registrations to anatomical and output spaces). Gridded (volumetric) resamplings were performed using antsApplyTransforms (ANTs), configured with Lanczos interpolation to minimize the smoothing effects of other kernels (Lanczos 1964). Non-gridded (surface) resamplings were performed using mri_vol2surf (FreeSurfer).

In FSL's FEAT (FMRI Expert Analysis Tool), spatial smoothing will be done using a Gaussian kernel with a full-width-at-half-maximum of 5 mm. High-pass filter cutoff will be set at 90 s.

fMRI – step 3. Statistical analyses: 
1.	First level analyses of the participant for the contrast threatening videos vs. neutral videos using FEAT. Threat and neutral videos as well as the instruction picture of own child will be modeled separately as a square-wave function. Each predictor will be convolved with a double gamma hemodynamic response function. Temporal derivatives will be added to the model and the contrast threat versus neutral will be assessed.
2.	All first-level contrast images and the corresponding variance images will be submitted to second level mixed-effects group whole brain analyses. Group level analysis will be performed using FEAT to detect average activation for the contrast threat vs. neutral and the reverse contrast. Statistical maps will be thresholded using clusters determined by Z > 3.1 and a cluster corrected significance threshold of p < .05. When no significant effects are observed for this threshold, the threshold will be lowered to Z > 2.3. Using the COPES resulting from the positive threat vs neutral contrast, masks will be created and used as the input for a featquery extracting the individual Z mean values for all significant clusters. 
3.	These individual Z values will be used for further confirmatory and exploratory analyses.

question2c.value:
Confirmatory
1.	Pearson (or Spearman in case transformation of variables does not result in normally distributed variables) correlation will be calculated to examine the associations between participants’ observed protective behavior and reported protective behavior (partner- and self-report). When significant correlations are observed between observed and reported protective behavior, a Principal Component Analysis will be performed, including the AST score, the PPQ mean score of the participant and the PPQ mean score of the partner, to test whether these three measurements load on one component, indicating a latent variable “Protective behavior”. If so, the component scores will be used in subsequent correlational and mediation analyses. If no significant correlations are observed, observed protective behavior and reported protective behavior (partner- and self-report) will be taken into account as two separate constructs in the correlation tests described below in step 2 and in the exploratory mediation analyses.

2.	The relation between the neural, behavioral and hormonal measurements will be assessed. Only neural clusters that include brain areas involved in the parental care network, visual processing areas or threat detection (as reported in Van ‘t Veer et al., 2019) will be included in the current confirmatory analyses. All data will be checked for parametric assumptions. If met, Pearson correlations will be calculated between each measure (see Figure 1.). If not met, data will be transformed to achieve or approach a normal distribution. When the transformation does not result in a normal distribution, Spearman correlations will be performed in sensitivity analyses. Significance will be set on p < .05. To control for multiple testing, a Benjamini-Hochberg correction will be applied.

Co-registration was configured with six degrees of freedom. Head-motion parameters with respect to the BOLD reference (transformation matrices, and six corresponding rotation and translation parameters) are estimated before any spatiotemporal filtering using mcflirt (FSL 5.0.9, Jenkinson et al. 2002). BOLD runs were slice-time corrected using 3dTshift from AFNI 20160207 (Cox and Hyde 1997, RRID:SCR_005927). The BOLD time-series, were resampled to surfaces on the following spaces: fsaverage6. The BOLD time-series (including slice-timing correction when applied) were resampled onto their original, native space by applying a single, composite transform to correct for head-motion and susceptibility distortions. These resampled BOLD time-series will be referred to as preprocessed BOLD in original space, or just preprocessed BOLD. The BOLD time-series were resampled into several standard spaces, correspondingly generating the following spatially-normalized, preprocessed BOLD runs: MNI152NLin2009cAsym, MNI152NLin6Asym. First, a reference volume and its skull-stripped version were generated using a custom methodology of fMRIPrep. Automatic removal of motion artifacts using independent component analysis (ICA-AROMA, Pruim et al. 2015) was performed on the preprocessed BOLD on MNI space time-series after removal of non-steady state volumes and spatial smoothing with an isotropic, Gaussian kernel of 6mm FWHM (full-width half-maximum). Corresponding “non-aggresively” denoised runs were produced after such smoothing. Additionally, the “aggressive” noise-regressors were collected and placed in the corresponding confounds file. Several confounding time-series were calculated based on the preprocessed BOLD: framewise displacement (FD), DVARS and three region-wise global signals. FD and DVARS are calculated for each functional run, both using their implementations in Nipype (following the definitions by Power et al. 2014). The three global signals are extracted within the CSF, the WM, and the whole-brain masks. Additionally, a set of physiological regressors were extracted to allow for component-based noise correction (CompCor, Behzadi et al. 2007). Principal components are estimated after high-pass filtering the preprocessed BOLD time-series (using a discrete cosine filter with 128s cut-off) for the two CompCor variants: temporal (tCompCor) and anatomical (aCompCor). tCompCor components are then calculated from the top 5% variable voxels within a mask covering the subcortical regions. This subcortical mask is obtained by heavily eroding the brain mask, which ensures it does not include cortical GM regions. For aCompCor, components are calculated within the intersection of the aforementioned mask and the union of CSF and WM masks calculated in T1w space, after their projection to the native space of each functional run (using the inverse BOLD-to-T1w transformation). Components are also calculated separately within the WM and CSF masks. For each CompCor decomposition, the k components with the largest singular values are retained, such that the retained components’ time series are sufficient to explain 50 percent of variance across the nuisance mask (CSF, WM, combined, or temporal). The remaining components are dropped from consideration. The head-motion estimates calculated in the correction step were also placed within the corresponding confounds file. The confound time series derived from head motion estimates and global signals were expanded with the inclusion of temporal derivatives and quadratic terms for each (Satterthwaite et al. 2013). Frames that exceeded a threshold of 0.5 mm FD or 1.5 standardised DVARS were annotated as motion outliers. All resamplings can be performed with a single interpolation step by composing all the pertinent transformations (i.e. head-motion transform matrices, susceptibility distortion correction when available, and co-registrations to anatomical and output spaces). Gridded (volumetric) resamplings were performed using antsApplyTransforms (ANTs), configured with Lanczos interpolation to minimize the smoothing effects of other kernels (Lanczos 1964). Non-gridded (surface) resamplings were performed using mri_vol2surf (FreeSurfer).

In FSL's FEAT (FMRI Expert Analysis Tool), spatial smoothing will be done using a Gaussian kernel with a full-width-at-half-maximum of 5 mm. High-pass filter cutoff will be set at 90 s.

fMRI – step 3. Statistical analyses: 
1.	First level analyses of the participant for the contrast threatening videos vs. neutral videos using FEAT. Threat and neutral videos as well as the instruction picture of own child will be modeled separately as a square-wave function. Each predictor will be convolved with a double gamma hemodynamic response function. Temporal derivatives will be added to the model and the contrast threat versus neutral will be assessed.
2.	All first-level contrast images and the corresponding variance images will be submitted to second level mixed-effects group whole brain analyses. Group level analysis will be performed using FEAT to detect average activation for the contrast threat vs. neutral and the reverse contrast. Statistical maps will be thresholded using clusters determined by Z > 3.1 and a cluster corrected significance threshold of p < .05. When no significant effects are observed for this threshold, the threshold will be lowered to Z > 2.3. Using the COPES resulting from the positive threat vs neutral contrast, masks will be created and used as the input for a featquery extracting the individual Z mean values for all significant clusters. 
3.	These individual Z values will be used for further confirmatory and exploratory analyses.

question2c.value:
Exploratory analyses: Correlations between other neural clusters, activating on the contrast threat vs. neutral and the reverse contrast neutral vs. threat, and behavioral and hormonal measurements will be assessed.
All data will be checked for parametric assumptions. If met, Pearson correlations will be calculated between each measure (see Figure 1.). If not met, data will be transformed to achieve or approach a normal distribution. When the transformation does not result in a normal distribution, Spearman correlations will be performed in sensitivity analyses.

The age of the participant at time of the first assessment – basal hormonal levels; 5. Excessive physical exercise – basal hormonal levels; 6. Recent alcohol use - basal hormonal levels; 7. Recent caffeine use – basal hormonal levels. Variables will be taken into account as a covariate for the specific bivariate correlation test when a significant relation is observed via residualizing.

registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question1a:
The current study aims to explore the neurobiological correlates of paternal protection. 
1.	We hypothesize that the different indicators of paternal protection (protective behavior, neural responses to infant threat, and testosterone and vasopressin levels) are positively related to each other (Figure 1.): 
a.	Based on expected construct validity, we expect a significant positive relation between observed and reported protective behavior. 
b.	Based on previous literature, we expect a positive association between baseline testosterone (T) and vasopressin (AVP) levels and neural reactivity to threatening stimuli in brain areas involved the parental care network, visual processing areas and threat detection. 
c.	Based on previous literature, we expect a positive association between baseline T and AVP levels and protective behavior. 
d.	Based on previous literature, we expect a positive association between protective behavior and neural reactivity to threatening stimuli in brain areas involved in the parental care network, visual processing areas and threat detection.
2.	Based on the biological interaction between hormones and the brain, it is speculated that the relation between salivary hormone levels and protective behavior is mediated by neural responses in brain areas involved in the parental care network, visual processing areas and threat detection (Figure 2.). We expect that higher basal T and AVP levels are related to higher protective parenting, when increased neural reactivity is observed.
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question3a:
-	Neuro-imaging data: threatening videos result in a significant different neural response compared to neutral videos. 
-	Observed protective behavior: a sudden loud sound is present during father-infant interaction.
registration_responses.recommended-hypothesis.question5a:
An important aspect of parental care, however largely neglected in parenting research, is infant protection (Bakermans-Kranenburg & Van IJzendoorn, 2017). Parental protective behavior may be important for the promotion of secure attachment. Specifically, experiences with protective parents may enhance children’s trust in parent’s availability to help and protect them in times of danger or distress (Bowbly, 1982). Since most research on protective parenting concentrated on mothers (Hahn-Holbrook, Holbrook, & Haselton, 2011), the current study aims to address the psychobiology of protective behavior in fathers. 
Paternal protective behavior has been studied in a variety of contexts, however, to our knowledge, only few studies combined behavioral, neural or endocrine aspects to address the psychobiology of paternal behavior. For example, males’ behavioral and neural responses have been studied during exposure to infant crying, an indicator for a possible threatening situation (e.g. Alyousefi-Van Dijk et al., 2019; Li, Chen, Mascaro, Haroon, & Rilling, 2017; Thijssen et al., 2018; Van Anders, Tolman, & Volling, 2012). Furthermore, fathers’ protective behavior and neural responses towards the (unborn) child in daily life situations have been studied (e.g. Van ’t Veer, Thijssen, Witteman, Van IJzendoorn, & Bakermans-Kranenburg, 2019). Moreover, several literature reviews concluded that paternal behavior has a possible neuro-endocrine basis (Abraham & Feldman, 2018; Hahn-Holbrook et al., 2011; Rilling & Mascaro, 2017), indicating that paternal hormones, such as testosterone and vasopressin, and specific neural activation might be proper correlates or even activators of observed protective behavior. 

The possible role of testosterone and vasopressin in protective parenting has been incorporated in the Steroid/Peptide Model of Social Bonds by Van Anders, Goldey, & Kuo (2011). Firstly, their model implies that low levels of testosterone might be linked to parental contexts that are perceived as nurturing. This statement is in line with previous research showing that lower salivary testosterone is associated with increased participation of fathers in child care and enhanced quality of caregiving, both prenatally (Bos et al., 2018; Edelstein et al., 2017) and postnatally (Bos et al., 2018; Gettler, McDade, Feranil, & Kuzawa, 2011; Weisman, Zagoory-Sharon, & Feldman, 2014), although combined effect sizes are small (for meta-analysis see Meijer, Van IJzendoorn, & Bakermans - Kranenburg, 2019). Additionally, the model of Van Anders and colleagues implies that high levels of testosterone are associated with parental contexts that involve a need for protective responses. Indeed, it was shown that testosterone administration increased males’ neural responses to facial threat cues in brain areas associated with threat processing (Goetz et al., 2014) and that cry sounds increased salivary testosterone levels in men when no nurturing action was possible (Van Anders et al., 2012). Based on these findings, we expect a positive association between baseline testosterone levels, protective behavior and neural reactivity to threatening stimuli. 
Secondly, the Steroid/Peptide Model states a specific role for AVP reactivity in protective parenting, namely that protective aggression is positively related to increases of AVP (Van Anders et al., 2011). A number of studies suggest that paternal protection might be associated with AVP. For instance, administration of AVP increased father-to-be’s orientation towards baby avatars (Cohen-Bendahan, Beijers, Van Doornen, & de Weerth, 2015) and it affected the neural processing of emotionally labeled infant cry sounds (Thijssen et al., 2018). Moreover, basal AVP levels in fathers have been shown to be negatively related to brain activity in brain areas involved in empathy and social cognition when viewing neutral or positive videos of own infant vs other infant. The authors interpreted this as a possible AVP-dependent vigilance to strangers (Atzil, Hendler, Zagoory-Sharon, Winetraub, & Feldman, 2012). In contrast, other studies showed that AVP administration did not increase handgrip force in reaction to infant crying in first time expectant fathers (Alyousefi-Van Dijk et al., 2019) or fathers’ neural processing of infant cry and the subjective cry rating (Li et al., 2017), and no correlation between basal AVP levels and explicit and implicit infant caregiving was observed in prospective fathers (Cohen-Bendahan et al., 2015). Thus, mixed findings are present for the role of AVP, both for basal and reactive hormone levels, in protective behavior. However, no studies to date specifically looked at AVP in relation to protective paternal behavior and neural processing of infant threat. Based on previous findings and the theory of the Steroid/Peptide Model, we predict that basal levels of AVP are associated with more protective behavior and stronger neural responses to infant threat. 

	To our knowledge, few studies have focused on the relation between protective behavior and its neural correlates. An fMRI study with fathers focusing on dangerous daily situations revealed that several brain networks known to be associated with the parental care network, visual processing areas and threat detection, are involved in processing of videos depicting infant threatening situations (Van ’t Veer et al., 2019). Moreover, Van ‘t Veer and colleagues observed that protective behavior in daily life was linked to stronger brain activation while watching their own (versus an unknown) infant in threatening (versus neutral) situations. Based on these findings, we hypothesize a neural threat component that will be positively associated with observed and reported protective behavior.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2a:
Exploratory mediation analyses (all between-participant, continuous variables): 
-	Salivary testosterone
-	Salivary vasopressin
-	Neural responses in reaction to infant threat
The Steroid/Peptide Model state that both T and AVP might be positively associated with protective parenting. Therefore, we expect a positive correlation between basal salivary hormone levels. 
Furthermore, we expect a positive correlation between salivary hormones and neural responses to infant threat. This will be tested in the confirmatory analyses.
