registration_responses.description-methods.design.question3b: Covariates: It will be tested whether there is a significant relation between 1. Baby state during Auditory Startling Task (AST) noise – observed protective response during the AST; 2. Number of days between the start date of the intervention and the date the PPQ was answered; 3. The time of saliva collection – basal hormonal levels; 4. The age of the participant at time of the first assessment – basal hormonal levels; 5. Excessive physical exercise – basal hormonal levels; 6. Recent alcohol use -  basal hormonal levels; 7. Recent caffeine use – basal hormonal levels. Variables will be taken into account as a covariate for the specific bivariate correlation test when a significant relation is observed via residualizing.
registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question6c: To control for multiple testing, a Benjamini-Hochberg correction will be applied.
registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question7c: Missing data will be imputed via Multiple Imputation with the R package ‘mice’ (Van Buuren & Groothuis-Oudshoorn, 2011). For the construction of the imputation model, all variables included in the exploratory and confirmatory analyses and auxiliary variables were taken into account. Selected auxiliary variables are age of the infant at time of the first assessment, start time of the first assessment, scored baby state before AST noise. The multiply imputed data will be pooled in the confirmatory and the exploratory analyses.
registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question8c: Parental Protection Questionnaire: Exploratory Factor Analysis will be performed to determine how many underlying factors are present in the questionnaire data. Items loading on eigenvalue >.40 on the factor explaining the most of the variance will be selected. A Cronbach’s alpha will be calculated to assess the internal consistency of these selected items.
registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question10c: Confirmatory and exploratory correlational analyses: All data will be checked for parametric assumptions. If met, Pearson correlations will be calculated between each measure. If not met, data will be transformed to achieve or approach a normal distribution. When the transformation does not result in a normal distribution, Spearman correlations will be performed in sensitivity analyses. Significance will be set on p < .05.
registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10:
Procedure 
Participants were invited for three assessments, with the pretest approximately 8-17 weeks after birth, the posttest approximately 12-21 weeks after birth, and a follow-up around 29-45 weeks post-birth. The first two research visits were located either in the Leiden University Medical Centre (LUMC) or at the participant’s home, depending on possible MRI contra-indications (i.e. diabetes, neurological diagnosis, metallic foreign objects in participant’s body) and preference of the participant. Between the pretest and posttest, participants received an instruction about the intervention and were asked to use the assigned baby tool, either a baby seat or a baby carrier, for three weeks, for a minimal of six hours per week divided over at least four days. Between the post-test and follow-up, participants could keep the assigned tool and use it as often as they preferred. The study is approved by the Ethics Committees of the Leiden University Medical Centre and of the Department of Education and Child studies at Leiden University. All participants gave informed consent. For the current paper, we focus on the pretest assessment.

The pretest assessment consisted of at least three parts: 1. Behavioral measurements, including a 10 minute Free play (Witte, De Moor, Van Ijzendoorn, & Bakermans-Kranenburg, 2019), the Auditory Startling Task (AST, Witte et al., 2019), a handgrip force paradigm (Alyousefi-Van Dijk et al., 2019), and the Five Minute Speech Sample (Lotz et al., 2020); 2. Saliva and hair sampling for hormonal measurements; and 3. Questionnaires about e.g. health, medication and current mental state. When the assessment took place in the LUMC, additional neural measurements were taken with (f)MRI and DTI. Following the assessment, participants and partners completed some online questionnaires at home (including the Parental Protection Questionnaire; See Van ’t Veer et al., 2019). 


Measures
Auditory Startling task .To observe paternal protective behavior, we applied the Auditory Startling Task (Witte et al., 2019). During the AST, a loud short sound fragment was played “unexpectedly” by a hidden audio installation while the participant was playing with his infant. Participant and infant were playing alone in a separate room while being videotaped. The sound consisted of white noise (80-db) and was programmed for 10 seconds with short breaks. At the end of the sound fragment, the researcher entered the room and apologized for the sound: e.g. ‘I am sorry for the sound, we had some technical problems’. The purpose of the sound fragment was explained to the participants at the end of the follow-up visit. 
Protective behavior of the participant towards the infant in reaction to the sound fragment, and baby states before and during the sound fragment were coded from the video. The baby state before the sound fragment was coded based on observation of the 30 seconds before the start of the white noise. The baby state during the sound fragment was also coded. Coding of the protective behavior in reaction to the white noise was stopped when the researcher entered the room.

The coding manual was developed for the current study. Two authors (MBK & AL) watched 10 AST videos and listed the observed protective responses and added other possible protective behaviors in reaction to the auditory stimuli. Subsequently, 10 members of the research team, including MBK and AL, rated these behaviors on protective behavior (1= least protective; 8= most protective). A correlation matrix of these ratings revealed that all r > .80, indicating that in general all raters agreed on rating order. The final coding scheme consists of a 10-point scale, with higher scores reflecting more protective behavior, see Table 1 for an overview. The coding scheme for baby states before and during noise was adapted from Mah, Bakermans-Kranenburg, Van Ijzendoorn, & Smith (2015) and consists of a 5-point scale: 1. Drowsy or asleep, 2. Quiet, 3. Alert, 4. Startled, 5. Fussing, 6. Distressed. When various states or responses were observed, the highest rating corresponding to these responses was assigned
Five raters were trained by one of the authors (AL). Interrater reliability was assessed based on a total of 20 videos. A first set of ten videos was scored directly after the training. A second set of ten videos was coded after all raters coded several videos independently. All raters obtained good inter rater reliability (Single measures absolute agreement, Parental protection ICC > .84, Baby state before noise ICC > .67, Baby state during noise ICC > .75). 

fMRI protection task. To examine the possible neural basis for paternal protection, fathers participated in an fMRI task that was adapted from Van ‘t Veer et al. (2019). In the current protection task, as described in Witte et al. (2019), participants watched videos while lying in an MRI scanner. The videos depicted either a scenario in which an infant was in a threatening situation, or a matched neutral video in which there was no threat to the infant. During the task, participants watched 12 different video pairs (see table 2. for a description of the videos). The videos (that will be made available upon request) were filmed using a gender-neutral lifelike baby doll. Fathers were instructed to imagine that the infant in the videos was their own infant. To ease the task of imagining their own infant in the videos, a picture of their infant was shown during the task. Moreover, the presentation of the doll’s face and the faces of the actors in the videos was minimized.
Each video, 12 threatening videos and 12 matched neutral videos, was shown twice to each participant, resulting in a total of 48 videos. The duration of each video was 6 seconds. The videos were shown in one of four pre-programmed semi-random orders. The order was selected based on participant identification number (1 assigned to order 1, 4 to order 4, 5 to order 1, etc.). For each order, it was ensured that videos were equally distributed across the task: 12 neutral and 12 threatening videos were presented during the first half of the task as well as the second half of the task. To maximize the power of the design, inter stimulus interval (ISI) between videos was sampled using the web-based tool Neurodesign (Durnez, Blair, & Poldrack, 2017). Videos were separated by an ISI of variable length ranging from 3.0 – 8.0 seconds, with a mean ISI of 4.5 seconds. The task was programmed in E-Prime software (version 2.0; Psychology Software Tools, Inc., PA, USA).

Prior to the first assessment, participants were asked to send a picture of their own child. Each photo was edited in Adobe Photoshop CS by adding a black-face contour to remove ears and most of the hair, and a black background. To ensure that all images contain approximately the same pixel ratio between the black background and face, images were resized so that face length was set on 10 cm. Finally, a selection of the picture containing the face was copied to a new black image of 640*480 pixels. Participants were familiarized to the edited image and task design during a practice task prior to the MRI scan session, while viewing videos that were not included in the real task. At the onset of the real task, an edited picture of participants own infant was shown with a written instruction to imagine that their own infant is displayed in the succeeding videos. The instruction and edited picture were shown again after each eight videos (thus six times in total). After a stimulus interval of 250 milliseconds, the instruction screen advanced to one of the four pre-programmed semi-random order of 48 videos as described above. 

fMRI parameters. MRI scanning was performed on a 3 T Philips Achieva TXMRI system (Philips Medical Systems, Best, the Netherlands). For registration purposes, a T1-weighted anatomical scan was acquired (repetition time (TR)= 7.90 ms, echo time (TE) =  3.50 ms, flip angle = 8°, 155 transverse slices, ACQ voxel size 1.1 × 1.1 × 1.1 mm). The fMRI-task utilized a gradient-echo blood oxygen level dependent (BOLD) echo-planar imaging sequence with: TR = 2200 ms, TE = 30 ms, flip angle = 80°, 38 transverse slices, and ACQ voxel size of 2.75 × 2.75 × 2.75 mm (including a default interslice gap). The duration of the fMRI paradigm was 10 min 53 s (290 volumes). Fieldmap corrections were performed using a multi-acquisition B0 map, performed directly after the end of the fMRI protection task. 

Parental Protection Questionnaire. To measure father’s protective behavior towards the child in daily life, fathers and partners were asked to fill in the Parental Protection Questionnaire (PPQ, see Van ‘t Veer et al. (2019) for a prenatal version of this questionnaire) after each assessment. The partners reported on the participants’ protective behavior as well. The current questionnaire contains 12 items that had to be scored on the prevalence during the past month (1= never, 2= seldom, 3= sometimes, 4= often or always, 5= not applicable). Examples of questions are: ‘I made sure that the baby’s diaper was changed in time’, or ‘I made sure that the living room was safe for the baby’. Using an exploratory factor analysis on participants’ data, items loading >.40 on the factor explaining the most of the variance will be selected to calculate the mean score for both participant and partner.

Salivary vasopressin/testosterone. Salivary samples were obtained at the beginning of each assessment. Participants were instructed not to consume any alcoholic drinks or have excessive physical exercise during the last 24 hours prior to each assessment. Furthermore, participants were asked not to drink any caffeine containing drinks on the day of the assessment, and not to smoke, chew gum, eat or drink (except for water) 30 minutes before the start of the appointment. Just before sampling participants rinsed their mouth with water. All samples were stored as soon as possible at -20 ˚C. Saliva collected at home were placed on ice for transportation. 

Testosterone. Participants drool approximately 1.5 ml saliva into a 2 ml cryogenic vial (SalivaBio, Salimetrics), either directly into the vial or indirectly using a saliva collection aid (Saliva Bio, Salimetrics). Before drooling, participants were asked to swallow once and to slightly bent forward. To stimulate saliva production, participants were recommended to think about something sweet or sour, to move their jaws up and down, or to look at pictures of food that were provided. Testosterone was quantified at Dresden LabService GmbH (Germany) by Luminscence enzyme immunoassay (IBL International GMBH). Fifty µL of each sample was used for the immunoassay. The limit of detection was 1.8 pg/mL. Samples used for the current article were quantified in the same assay run (12 plates in total). Duplicate analyses was performed for a random selection of 30% of the samples. Inter-assay variability was 10% and intra-assay variability was 5.22%. Cross-reactivity with other substances tested < 0.01 %.

Vasopressin. Participants chewed on a cotton swab (Salivette, Sarstedt) for 60 seconds. Saliva for the quantification of OT and AVP was collected using salivettes (Sarstedt). Participants were instructed to chew lightly on a cotton swab for 60 seconds and move the swab around in their mouth every now and then to boost saliva collection. Researchers kept track of the time using a stopwatch. Oxytocin and vasopressin were quantified by radioimunnoassay at RIAgnosis (Sinzing, Germany). Salivettes were centrifuged at 4 degrees Celsius for 30 minutes with ca. 5000 g centrifugal force, after which 0.6 ml of saliva was pipetted into a vial (0.3 ml for the analysis of OT and 0.3 ml for the analysis of AVP). Both for OT and AVP and the detection limit was 0.1 pg/ml. All pre-test samples were analyzed simultaneously in the same assay run. Intra-assay variability was < 10%. There is no significant cross-reactivity with other neuropeptides (< 0.7%).
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi:
Preprocessing of AST
It will be checked whether data for the three scales (protective response, baby state before noise and baby state during noise) is normally distributed and whether outliers are present in the data. When needed data will be transformed to achieve a normal distribution. 


Preprocessing of baseline hormone levels
It will be checked whether the data is normally distributed and whether outliers are present in the data. When needed, data will be transformed to achieve a normal distribution.


Preprocessing PPQ
PPQ – step 1. Participants’ responses - the validation of the questionnaire:
Exploratory Factor Analysis will be performed to determine how many underlying factors are present in the questionnaire data. Items loading on eigenvalue >.4 will be selected. A Cronbach’s alpha will be calculated to assess the internal consistency of these selected items. Based on the selected items, a mean score will be calculated.

PPQ – step 2. Partners’ responses: 
Items selected based in step 1 are selected from the partners questionnaires. A Cronbach’s alpha will be calculated to assess the internal consistency for these items. Based on the selected items, a mean score will be calculated. 


Preprocessing fMRI
fMRI – step 1. Data is structured following the Brain Imaging Data Structure (BIDS). Firstly, Dicom scans collected during the fMRI protection task were converted to .nifti and .json files via the dcm2niix converter. Subsequently, the .nifti files and corresponding stimulus data were checked via the BIDS validator. 

fMRI – step 2. Preprocessing is performed using fMRIPrep (version ≥1.5.2 (Esteban, Markiewicz, et al. (2018); Esteban, Blair, et al. (2018); RRID:SCR_016216)), which is based on Nipype 1.3.1 (Gorgolewski et al. (2011); Gorgolewski et al. (2018); RRID:SCR_002502).
Anatomical data preprocessing. T1-weighted (T1w) images were corrected for intensity non-uniformity (INU) with N4BiasFieldCorrection,(Tustison et al. 2010), distributed with ANTs 2.2.0 (Avants et al. 2008, RRID:SCR_004757). The T1w-reference was then skull-stripped with Nipype implementation of the antsBrainExtraction.sh workflow (from ANTs), using OASIS30ANTs as target template. Brain tissue segmentation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), white-matter (WM) and gray-matter (GM) was performed on the brain-extracted T1w using fast (FSL 5.0.9, RRID:SCR_002823, Zhang, Brady, and Smith 2001). A T1w-reference map was computed after registration of T1w images (after INU-correction) using mri_robust_template (FreeSurfer 6.0.1, Reuter, Rosas, and Fischl 2010). Brain surfaces were reconstructed using recon-all (FreeSurfer 6.0.1, RRID:SCR_001847, Dale, Fischl, and Sereno 1999), and the brain mask estimated previously was refined with a custom variation of the method to reconcile ANTs-derived and FreeSurfer-derived segmentations of the cortical gray-matter of Mindboggle (RRID:SCR_002438, Klein et al. 2017). Volume-based spatial normalization to two standard spaces (MNI152NLin2009cAsym, MNI152NLin6Asym) was performed through nonlinear registration with antsRegistration (ANTs 2.2.0), using brain-extracted versions of both T1w reference and the T1w template. The following templates were selected for spatial normalization: ICBM 152 Nonlinear Asymmetrical template version 2009c [Fonov et al. (2009), RRID:SCR_008796; TemplateFlow ID: MNI152NLin2009cAsym], FSL’s MNI ICBM 152 non-linear 6th Generation Asymmetric Average Brain Stereotaxic Registration Model [Evans et al. (2012), RRID:SCR_002823; TemplateFlow ID: MNI152NLin6Asym].
Functional data preprocessing. For each BOLD run, the following preprocessing was performed. First, a reference volume and its skull-stripped version were generated using a custom methodology of fMRIPrep. A deformation field to correct for susceptibility distortions was estimated based on fMRIPrep’s fieldmap-less approach. The deformation field is that resulting from co-registering the BOLD reference to the same-subject T1w-reference with its intensity inverted (Wang et al. 2017; Huntenburg 2014). Registration is performed with antsRegistration (ANTs 2.2.0), and the process regularized by constraining deformation to be nonzero only along the phase-encoding direction, and modulated with an average fieldmap template (Treiber et al. 2016). Based on the estimated susceptibility distortion, an unwarped BOLD reference was calculated for a more accurate co-registration with the anatomical reference. The BOLD reference was then co-registered to the T1w reference using bbregister (FreeSurfer) which implements boundary-based registration (Greve and Fischl 2009). Co-registration was configured with six degrees of freedom. Head-motion parameters with respect to the BOLD reference (transformation matrices, and six corresponding rotation and translation parameters) are estimated before any spatiotemporal filtering using mcflirt (FSL 5.0.9, Jenkinson et al. 2002). BOLD runs were slice-time corrected using 3dTshift from AFNI 20160207 (Cox and Hyde 1997, RRID:SCR_005927). The BOLD time-series, were resampled to surfaces on the following spaces: fsaverage6. The BOLD time-series (including slice-timing correction when applied) were resampled onto their original, native space by applying a single, composite transform to correct for head-motion and susceptibility distortions. These resampled BOLD time-series will be referred to as preprocessed BOLD in original space, or just preprocessed BOLD. The BOLD time-series were resampled into several standard spaces, correspondingly generating the following spatially-normalized, preprocessed BOLD runs: MNI152NLin2009cAsym, MNI152NLin6Asym. First, a reference volume and its skull-stripped version were generated using a custom methodology of fMRIPrep. Automatic removal of motion artifacts using independent component analysis (ICA-AROMA, Pruim et al. 2015) was performed on the preprocessed BOLD on MNI space time-series after removal of non-steady state volumes and spatial smoothing with an isotropic, Gaussian kernel of 6mm FWHM (full-width half-maximum). Corresponding “non-aggresively” denoised runs were produced after such smoothing. Additionally, the “aggressive” noise-regressors were collected and placed in the corresponding confounds file. Several confounding time-series were calculated based on the preprocessed BOLD: framewise displacement (FD), DVARS and three region-wise global signals. FD and DVARS are calculated for each functional run, both using their implementations in Nipype (following the definitions by Power et al. 2014). The three global signals are extracted within the CSF, the WM, and the whole-brain masks. Additionally, a set of physiological regressors were extracted to allow for component-based noise correction (CompCor, Behzadi et al. 2007). Principal components are estimated after high-pass filtering the preprocessed BOLD time-series (using a discrete cosine filter with 128s cut-off) for the two CompCor variants: temporal (tCompCor) and anatomical (aCompCor). tCompCor components are then calculated from the top 5% variable voxels within a mask covering the subcortical regions. This subcortical mask is obtained by heavily eroding the brain mask, which ensures it does not include cortical GM regions. For aCompCor, components are calculated within the intersection of the aforementioned mask and the union of CSF and WM masks calculated in T1w space, after their projection to the native space of each functional run (using the inverse BOLD-to-T1w transformation). Components are also calculated separately within the WM and CSF masks. For each CompCor decomposition, the k components with the largest singular values are retained, such that the retained components’ time series are sufficient to explain 50 percent of variance across the nuisance mask (CSF, WM, combined, or temporal). The remaining components are dropped from consideration. The head-motion estimates calculated in the correction step were also placed within the corresponding confounds file. The confound time series derived from head motion estimates and global signals were expanded with the inclusion of temporal derivatives and quadratic terms for each (Satterthwaite et al. 2013). Frames that exceeded a threshold of 0.5 mm FD or 1.5 standardised DVARS were annotated as motion outliers. All resamplings can be performed with a single interpolation step by composing all the pertinent transformations (i.e. head-motion transform matrices, susceptibility distortion correction when available, and co-registrations to anatomical and output spaces). Gridded (volumetric) resamplings were performed using antsApplyTransforms (ANTs), configured with Lanczos interpolation to minimize the smoothing effects of other kernels (Lanczos 1964). Non-gridded (surface) resamplings were performed using mri_vol2surf (FreeSurfer).

In FSL's FEAT (FMRI Expert Analysis Tool), spatial smoothing will be done using a Gaussian kernel with a full-width-at-half-maximum of 5 mm. High-pass filter cutoff will be set at 90 s.

fMRI – step 3. Statistical analyses: 
1.	First level analyses of the participant for the contrast threatening videos vs. neutral videos using FEAT. Threat and neutral videos as well as the instruction picture of own child will be modeled separately as a square-wave function. Each predictor will be convolved with a double gamma hemodynamic response function. Temporal derivatives will be added to the model and the contrast threat versus neutral will be assessed.
2.	All first-level contrast images and the corresponding variance images will be submitted to second level mixed-effects group whole brain analyses. Group level analysis will be performed using FEAT to detect average activation for the contrast threat vs. neutral and the reverse contrast. Statistical maps will be thresholded using clusters determined by Z > 3.1 and a cluster corrected significance threshold of p < .05. When no significant effects are observed for this threshold, the threshold will be lowered to Z > 2.3. Using the COPES resulting from the positive threat vs neutral contrast, masks will be created and used as the input for a featquery extracting the individual Z mean values for all significant clusters. 
3.	These individual Z values will be used for further confirmatory and exploratory analyses.

Confirmatory
1.	Pearson (or Spearman in case transformation of variables does not result in normally distributed variables) correlation will be calculated to examine the associations between participants’ observed protective behavior and reported protective behavior (partner- and self-report). When significant correlations are observed between observed and reported protective behavior, a Principal Component Analysis will be performed, including the AST score, the PPQ mean score of the participant and the PPQ mean score of the partner, to test whether these three measurements load on one component, indicating a latent variable “Protective behavior”. If so, the component scores will be used in subsequent correlational and mediation analyses. If no significant correlations are observed, observed protective behavior and reported protective behavior (partner- and self-report) will be taken into account as two separate constructs in the correlation tests described below in step 2 and in the exploratory mediation analyses.

2.	The relation between the neural, behavioral and hormonal measurements will be assessed. Only neural clusters that include brain areas involved in the parental care network, visual processing areas or threat detection (as reported in Van ‘t Veer et al., 2019) will be included in the current confirmatory analyses. All data will be checked for parametric assumptions. If met, Pearson correlations will be calculated between each measure (see Figure 1.). If not met, data will be transformed to achieve or approach a normal distribution. When the transformation does not result in a normal distribution, Spearman correlations will be performed in sensitivity analyses. Significance will be set on p < .05. To control for multiple testing, a Benjamini-Hochberg correction will be applied.

Variables in correlational design:
-	Protective behavior; depending on the PCA results, Protective behavior will comprised of observed and reported protective behavior (partner- and self-report) or separate analyses will be performed for observed and reported protective behavior.
-	Neural responses in reaction to infant threat. 
-	Salivary testosterone
-	Salivary vasopressin

It will be tested whether there is a significant relation between 1. Baby state during Auditory Startling Task (AST) noise – observed protective response during the AST; 2. Number of days between the start date of the intervention and the date the PPQ was answered; 3. The time of saliva collection – basal hormonal levels; 4. The age of the participant at time of the first assessment – basal hormonal levels; 5. Excessive physical exercise – basal hormonal levels; 6. Recent alcohol use - basal hormonal levels; 7. Recent caffeine use – basal hormonal levels. Variables will be taken into account as a covariate for the specific bivariate correlation test when a significant relation is observed via residualizing.

Several confounding time-series were calculated based on the preprocessed BOLD: framewise displacement (FD), DVARS and three region-wise global signals. FD and DVARS are calculated for each functional run, both using their implementations in Nipype (following the definitions by Power et al. 2014). The three global signals are extracted within the CSF, the WM, and the whole-brain masks. Additionally, a set of physiological regressors were extracted to allow for component-based noise correction (CompCor, Behzadi et al. 2007). Principal components are estimated after high-pass filtering the preprocessed BOLD time-series (using a discrete cosine filter with 128s cut-off) for the two CompCor variants: temporal (tCompCor) and anatomical (aCompCor). tCompCor components are then calculated from the top 5% variable voxels within a mask covering the subcortical regions. This subcortical mask is obtained by heavily eroding the brain mask, which ensures it does not include cortical GM regions. For aCompCor, components are calculated within the intersection of the aforementioned mask and the union of CSF and WM masks calculated in T1w space, after their projection to the native space of each functional run (using the inverse BOLD-to-T1w transformation). Components are also calculated separately within the WM and CSF masks. For each CompCor decomposition, the k components with the largest singular values are retained, such that the retained components’ time series are sufficient to explain 50 percent of variance across the nuisance mask (CSF, WM, combined, or temporal). The remaining components are dropped from consideration. The head-motion estimates calculated in the correction step were also placed within the corresponding confounds file. The confound time series derived from head motion estimates and global signals were expanded with the inclusion of temporal derivatives and quadratic terms for each (Satterthwaite et al. 2013). Frames that exceeded a threshold of 0.5 mm FD or 1.5 standardised DVARS were annotated as motion outliers. All resamplings can be performed with a single interpolation step by composing all the pertinent transformations (i.e. head-motion transform matrices, susceptibility distortion correction when available, and co-registrations to anatomical and output spaces). Gridded (volumetric) resamplings were performed using antsApplyTransforms (ANTs), configured with Lanczos interpolation to minimize the smoothing effects of other kernels (Lanczos 1964). Non-gridded (surface) resamplings were performed using mri_vol2surf (FreeSurfer).

In FSL's FEAT (FMRI Expert Analysis Tool), spatial smoothing will be done using a Gaussian kernel with a full-width-at-half-maximum of 5 mm. High-pass filter cutoff will be set at 90 s.

fMRI – step 3. Statistical analyses: 
1.	First level analyses of the participant for the contrast threatening videos vs. neutral videos using FEAT. Threat and neutral videos as well as the instruction picture of own child will be modeled separately as a square-wave function. Each predictor will be convolved with a double gamma hemodynamic response function. Temporal derivatives will be added to the model and the contrast threat versus neutral will be assessed.
2.	All first-level contrast images and the corresponding variance images will be submitted to second level mixed-effects group whole brain analyses. Group level analysis will be performed using FEAT to detect average activation for the contrast threat vs. neutral and the reverse contrast. Statistical maps will be thresholded using clusters determined by Z > 3.1 and a cluster corrected significance threshold of p < .05. When no significant effects are observed for this threshold, the threshold will be lowered to Z > 2.3. Using the COPES resulting from the positive threat vs neutral contrast, masks will be created and used as the input for a featquery extracting the individual Z mean values for all significant clusters. 
3.	These individual Z values will be used for further confirmatory and exploratory analyses.

Exploratory: Path-analysis will be used to explore the mediating effect of neural responses in brain areas involved in the parental care network, visual processing areas and threat detection on the relation between basal hormone levels and protective behavior (see figure 1). Depending on the PCA results, protective behavior will comprised of observed and reported protective behavior (partner- and self-report) or separate mediation analyses will be performed for observed and reported protective behavior. Analyses will be performed in R (R Development Core Team, 2013), using the Lavaan Package (Rosseel, 2012).

Exploratory mediation analyses (all between-participant, continuous variables): 
-	Salivary testosterone
-	Salivary vasopressin
-	Neural responses in reaction to infant threat
The Steroid/Peptide Model state that both T and AVP might be positively associated with protective parenting. Therefore, we expect a positive correlation between basal salivary hormone levels. 
Furthermore, we expect a positive correlation between salivary hormones and neural responses to infant threat. This will be tested in the confirmatory analyses. 

Dependent variables in exploratory mediation analyses: 
-	Neural responses in reaction to infant threat (=mediator as well). 
-	Protective behavior; a variable based on both observed paternal protective behavior and self-reported protective behavior.

It will be tested whether there is a significant relation between 1. Baby state during Auditory Startling Task (AST) noise – observed protective response during the AST; 2. Number of days between the start date of the intervention and the date the PPQ was answered; 3. The time of saliva collection – basal hormonal levels; 4. The age of the participant at time of the first assessment – basal hormonal levels; 5. Excessive physical exercise – basal hormonal levels; 6. Recent alcohol use - basal hormonal levels; 7. Recent caffeine use – basal hormonal levels. Variables will be taken into account as a covariate for the specific bivariate correlation test when a significant relation is observed via residualizing.
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: In order to be eligible to participate in this study, subjects must meet all of the following criteria: 1. Fathers who have had their first baby, male adults in the early postnatal phase of parenthood (child’s age = +/-2 month). 2. The baby is a full-term, healthy infant.

Data were collected during research visits at the Leiden University Medical Center (LUMC) and/or at the participant’s home. If the participant was eligible to undergo a MRI scan, the fMRI and AST data were collected during a research visit at the LUMC. AST data were never collected at participant’s home. Baseline salivary hormones were either collected at the LUMC or at home, depending where the research visit took place. The Parental Protection Questionnaire (PPQ) was always filled in at home by both the participant and his partner. The procedure of the data collection is described below.

The obtained sample size is 78 participants. A meta-analysis on the association between parenting behavior and T levels in fathers showed a combined effect size of Hedges’ g = 0.14, equivalent to r = .07 (Meijer et al., 2019). With our sample size, a combined effect size of r = .07 results in a power of .09 (at an alpha level of .05). However, the meta-analysis included studies with a broad range of parenting-related measures, and their relevance to parental protection is unclear. Hardly any study on protective parenting is available. It is thus difficult to estimate the power achieved with our sample size accurately. When taking into account the only effect size related to protective parenting (r = .46, Alyousefi- Van Dijk et al., 2019), power would be > .90, but this was a study with a small sample size and the confidence interval (CI) of the effect size is (.08, .72). We can, as an alternative, determine what effect sizes we can detect in our sample. This is necessary for those associations between neural, behavioral and hormonal measurements for which no effect sizes can be derived from the literature, and thus are more exploratory. Therefore, we computed what effects we can detect as significant with our sample. Power value was set at .80, alpha at .05, resulting in detectable effect sizes of r = .31. This effect size is larger than what we consider the smallest effect size of interest (SESOI, Lakens, Scheel, & Isager, 2018). We suggest that effect sizes r ≥ .08 are of interest for further study and replication, as this is the lower end of the CI around the effect size of the aforementioned study (determination of SESOI as suggested by Perugini, Gallucci, & Costantini, 2014, although ideally this should be based on the CI of a meta-analytic effect size of pertinent studies).
The inclusion of participants was ended half December 2019. Participants had to be able to come for the first assessment before the end of January 2020.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-second.second.ques:
Exploratory analyses:

Preprocessing of AST
It will be checked whether data for the three scales (protective response, baby state before noise and baby state during noise) is normally distributed and whether outliers are present in the data. When needed data will be transformed to achieve a normal distribution. 

Preprocessing of baseline hormone levels
It will be checked whether the data is normally distributed and whether outliers are present in the data. When needed, data will be transformed to achieve a normal distribution.

Preprocessing PPQ
PPQ – step 1. Participants’ responses - the validation of the questionnaire:
Exploratory Factor Analysis will be performed to determine how many underlying factors are present in the questionnaire data. Items loading on eigenvalue >.4 will be selected. A Cronbach’s alpha will be calculated to assess the internal consistency of these selected items. Based on the selected items, a mean score will be calculated.

PPQ – step 2. Partners’ responses: 
Items selected based in step 1 are selected from the partners questionnaires. A Cronbach’s alpha will be calculated to assess the internal consistency for these items. Based on the selected items, a mean score will be calculated. 

Preprocessing fMRI
fMRI – step 1. Data is structured following the Brain Imaging Data Structure (BIDS). Firstly, Dicom scans collected during the fMRI protection task were converted to .nifti and .json files via the dcm2niix converter. Subsequently, the .nifti files and corresponding stimulus data were checked via the BIDS validator. 

fMRI – step 2. Preprocessing is performed using fMRIPrep (version ≥1.5.2 (Esteban, Markiewicz, et al. (2018); Esteban, Blair, et al. (2018); RRID:SCR_016216)), which is based on Nipype 1.3.1 (Gorgolewski et al. (2011); Gorgolewski et al. (2018); RRID:SCR_002502).
Anatomical data preprocessing. T1-weighted (T1w) images were corrected for intensity non-uniformity (INU) with N4BiasFieldCorrection,(Tustison et al. 2010), distributed with ANTs 2.2.0 (Avants et al. 2008, RRID:SCR_004757). The T1w-reference was then skull-stripped with Nipype implementation of the antsBrainExtraction.sh workflow (from ANTs), using OASIS30ANTs as target template. Brain tissue segmentation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), white-matter (WM) and gray-matter (GM) was performed on the brain-extracted T1w using fast (FSL 5.0.9, RRID:SCR_002823, Zhang, Brady, and Smith 2001). A T1w-reference map was computed after registration of T1w images (after INU-correction) using mri_robust_template (FreeSurfer 6.0.1, Reuter, Rosas, and Fischl 2010). Brain surfaces were reconstructed using recon-all (FreeSurfer 6.0.1, RRID:SCR_001847, Dale, Fischl, and Sereno 1999), and the brain mask estimated previously was refined with a custom variation of the method to reconcile ANTs-derived and FreeSurfer-derived segmentations of the cortical gray-matter of Mindboggle (RRID:SCR_002438, Klein et al. 2017). Volume-based spatial normalization to two standard spaces (MNI152NLin2009cAsym, MNI152NLin6Asym) was performed through nonlinear registration with antsRegistration (ANTs 2.2.0), using brain-extracted versions of both T1w reference and the T1w template. The following templates were selected for spatial normalization: ICBM 152 Nonlinear Asymmetrical template version 2009c [Fonov et al. (2009), RRID:SCR_008796; TemplateFlow ID: MNI152NLin2009cAsym], FSL’s MNI ICBM 152 non-linear 6th Generation Asymmetric Average Brain Stereotaxic Registration Model [Evans et al. (2012), RRID:SCR_002823; TemplateFlow ID: MNI152NLin6Asym].
Functional data preprocessing. For each BOLD run, the following preprocessing was performed. First, a reference volume and its skull-stripped version were generated using a custom methodology of fMRIPrep. A deformation field to correct for susceptibility distortions was estimated based on fMRIPrep’s fieldmap-less approach. The deformation field is that resulting from co-registering the BOLD reference to the same-subject T1w-reference with its intensity inverted (Wang et al. 2017; Huntenburg 2014). Registration is performed with antsRegistration (ANTs 2.2.0), and the process regularized by constraining deformation to be nonzero only along the phase-encoding direction, and modulated with an average fieldmap template (Treiber et al. 2016). Based on the estimated susceptibility distortion, an unwarped BOLD reference was calculated for a more accurate co-registration with the anatomical reference. The BOLD reference was then co-registered to the T1w reference using bbregister (FreeSurfer) which implements boundary-based registration (Greve and Fischl 2009). Co-registration was configured with six degrees of freedom. Head-motion parameters with respect to the BOLD reference (transformation matrices, and six corresponding rotation and translation parameters) are estimated before any spatiotemporal filtering using mcflirt (FSL 5.0.9, Jenkinson et al. 2002). BOLD runs were slice-time corrected using 3dTshift from AFNI 20160207 (Cox and Hyde 1997, RRID:SCR_005927). The BOLD time-series, were resampled to surfaces on the following spaces: fsaverage6. The BOLD time-series (including slice-timing correction when applied) were resampled onto their original, native space by applying a single, composite transform to correct for head-motion and susceptibility distortions. These resampled BOLD time-series will be referred to as preprocessed BOLD in original space, or just preprocessed BOLD. The BOLD time-series were resampled into several standard spaces, correspondingly generating the following spatially-normalized, preprocessed BOLD runs: MNI152NLin2009cAsym, MNI152NLin6Asym. First, a reference volume and its skull-stripped version were generated using a custom methodology of fMRIPrep. Automatic removal of motion artifacts using independent component analysis (ICA-AROMA, Pruim et al. 2015) was performed on the preprocessed BOLD on MNI space time-series after removal of non-steady state volumes and spatial smoothing with an isotropic, Gaussian kernel of 6mm FWHM (full-width half-maximum). Corresponding “non-aggresively” denoised runs were produced after such smoothing. Additionally, the “aggressive” noise-regressors were collected and placed in the corresponding confounds file. Several confounding time-series were calculated based on the preprocessed BOLD: framewise displacement (FD), DVARS and three region-wise global signals. FD and DVARS are calculated for each functional run, both using their implementations in Nipype (following the definitions by Power et al. 2014). The three global signals are extracted within the CSF, the WM, and the whole-brain masks. Additionally, a set of physiological regressors were extracted to allow for component-based noise correction (CompCor, Behzadi et al. 2007). This subcortical mask is obtained by heavily eroding the brain mask, which ensures it does not include cortical GM regions. For aCompCor, components are calculated within the intersection of the aforementioned mask and the union of CSF and WM masks calculated in T1w space, after their projection to the native space of each functional run (using the inverse BOLD-to-T1w transformation). Components are also calculated separately within the WM and CSF masks. For each CompCor decomposition, the k components with the largest singular values are retained, such that the retained components’ time series are sufficient to explain 50 percent of variance across the nuisance mask (CSF, WM, combined, or temporal). The remaining components are dropped from consideration. The head-motion estimates calculated in the correction step were also placed within the corresponding confounds file. The confound time series derived from head motion estimates and global signals were expanded with the inclusion of temporal derivatives and quadratic terms for each (Satterthwaite et al. 2013). Frames that exceeded a threshold of 0.5 mm FD or 1.5 standardised DVARS were annotated as motion outliers. All resamplings can be performed with a single interpolation step by composing all the pertinent transformations (i.e. head-motion transform matrices, susceptibility distortion correction when available, and co-registrations to anatomical and output spaces). Gridded (volumetric) resamplings were performed using antsApplyTransforms (ANTs), configured with Lanczos interpolation to minimize the smoothing effects of other kernels (Lanczos 1964). Non-gridded (surface) resamplings were performed using mri_vol2surf (FreeSurfer).

In FSL's FEAT (FMRI Expert Analysis Tool), spatial smoothing will be done using a Gaussian kernel with a full-width-at-half-maximum of 5 mm. High-pass filter cutoff will be set at 90 s.

fMRI – step 3. Statistical analyses: 
1.	First level analyses of the participant for the contrast threatening videos vs. neutral videos using FEAT. Threat and neutral videos as well as the instruction picture of own child will be modeled separately as a square-wave function. Each predictor will be convolved with a double gamma hemodynamic response function. Temporal derivatives will be added to the model and the contrast threat versus neutral will be assessed.
2.	All first-level contrast images and the corresponding variance images will be submitted to second level mixed-effects group whole brain analyses. Group level analysis will be performed using FEAT to detect average activation for the contrast threat vs. neutral and the reverse contrast. Statistical maps will be thresholded using clusters determined by Z > 3.1 and a cluster corrected significance threshold of p < .05. When no significant effects are observed for this threshold, the threshold will be lowered to Z > 2.3. Using the COPES resulting from the positive threat vs neutral contrast, masks will be created and used as the input for a featquery extracting the individual Z mean values for all significant clusters. 
3.	These individual Z values will be used for further confirmatory and exploratory analyses.

Exploratory analyses: Correlations between other neural clusters, activating on the contrast threat vs. neutral and the reverse contrast neutral vs. threat, and behavioral and hormonal measurements will be assessed.
All data will be checked for parametric assumptions. If met, Pearson correlations will be calculated between each measure (see Figure 1.). If not met, data will be transformed to achieve or approach a normal distribution. When the transformation does not result in a normal distribution, Spearman correlations will be performed in sensitivity analyses.

Variables in correlational design:
-	Protective behavior; depending on the PCA results, Protective behavior will comprised of observed and reported protective behavior (partner- and self-report) or separate mediation analyses will be performed for observed and reported protective behavior.
-	Neural responses in reaction to infant threat. 
-	Salivary testosterone
-	Salivary vasopressin

It will be tested whether there is a significant relation between 1. Baby state during Auditory Startling Task (AST) noise – observed protective response during the AST; 2. Number of days between the start date of the intervention and the date the PPQ was answered; 3. The time of saliva collection – basal hormonal levels; 4. The age of the participant at time of the first assessment – basal hormonal levels; 5. Excessive physical exercise – basal hormonal levels; 6. Recent alcohol use - basal hormonal levels; 7. Recent caffeine use – basal hormonal levels. Variables will be taken into account as a covariate for the specific bivariate correlation test when a significant relation is observed via residualizing.

attributes.title: Approach-Aversion 4 (Self initiated approach of the other)
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

additionalComments.value:
In the analyses, the data-based outliers criteria will be extreme values on studentized residuals (above 4), or a notable gap in terms of Cook-D and Leverage (see Judd & McClelland, 2011). Complementary analyses: We also plan to investigate the moderating role of the feeling of Presence (and its sub-dimensions: Social, physical and self-presence).

We will also note when participants will give wrong instructions to the virtual individuals and run the analysis with and without. However, as the script will continue only when correct instructions will be given we did not expect this will influence the results.

question2a.value:
a-	IV1: Movement (Approach vs. Static) – Within-participants variable. This variable will be operationalized through one step forward vs. no step of the virtual agent.
IV2: Threatening nature of the virtual character (Threatening vs. Not threatening). – Within-participants variable. This variable will be operationalized through the fact that participants initiate virtual individuals' movement (not threatening) or not (threatening).
b-	N/A

question10b.value: Participants will first sign a consent form. As a cover story, we will explain to them that we are developing a Virtual Reality (VR) application in which users can interact with others via their avatar. We will inform them that in the study they are taking part, we test if our application is able to reflect the impression that individuals give in real life. Thus, we will make them believe, that the virtual individuals they encounter are the avatars of real people and that they will have to give their global impression about each one of them. We also pretexted that at the same time we tested the sound detection sensitivity of our device and that they will have to indicate to some individuals where they have to position themselves by saying “Come here” or “Stay there”. Then, participants will be immersed in VR. Participants will put the VR headset with the experimenter’s assistance to enter the Immersive Virtual Reality Environment (IVRE). First, participants will familiarize with the VR in the bus stop and hear the instructions through headphones. Then, two training virtual individual will come in front of them (one for asking to come and one for asking to stay there), followed by the 16 critical ones (two men and two women in each of the four conditions). Half of virtual individuals will perform an approach movement toward participants once in front of them (approximately one step, finishing at 85 cm from participants) while the other half will stay on spot (at a distance of 110 cm from participants). For half virtual individuals in each movement condition, participants will have to request them to come (after a sound signal) and for the other half they will have to request them to stay there (after a different sound signal). For each individual, a Likert-type scale will appear in the virtual environment and participants will use the controllers to provide their impression toward him/her anchored at 1 (very negative) and 7 (very positive). For each participant, the order of trials as well as virtual individuals’ repartition within the four conditions will be randomly generated with R before the session. After performing the VR task, participants will complete the Presence questionnaire of Makransky, Lilleholt and Aaby (2017). At the end of this questionnaire, we will present some additional items. Participants will indicate any sickness symptoms (i.e., oculomotor troubles, disorientation and/or nausea due to the VR; 0 “Not at all”/1 “Slightly”/ 2 “A lot”/ 3 “Severely”) and report alcohol or illicit substance intake. We will ask participant their age, the gender they identify with and if they are fluent in French. Finally, participants will be probed for suspicion about the aim of the study and debriefed.

question5b.value: All the data will be collected in four experimental boxes at the Psychological Institute of Université de Paris in Boulogne-Billancourt (92100, FRANCE). Participants will be recruited on a voluntary basis, in exchange of a 5€ honorarium or credit course. All experimenters will be trained and will follow the same script.

question6b.value: Regarding the sample size, we plan to run at minimum 200 participants. Such a criterion enables us to detect an effect size η² of .004 with a power of 80%. Anticipating some data exclusions, we plan to collect data from approximately 220 participants.

question7b.value: We will stop registration to participate in the experiment when the 220 criterion is met.

question8b.value: a- We will exclude trials in the Virtual Reality task for which participants deviate from the instructed position (staying on spot). Moreover, a participant with more than 20% of this type of trials will be excluded from analysis. We will also exclude trials for which participants give an instruction to the virtual individuals when it is not required. b- We will exclude participants if they guess our hypothesis and/or express suspicion concerning the link between the movement and evaluation. c- We will exclude participants who are not fluent in French d- We will also exclude participants that indicate a “severe” sickness due to the VR or report alcohol or illicit substances consumption.

question1a.value:
Approach-aversion effect is the tendency to feel less positively (or more negatively) about a stimulus if it is approaching rather than static or receding (Hsee, Tu, Lu, & Ruan, 2014). This effect is supposed to arise because the stimulus appears more threatening when approaching rather than being static or receding. In this experiment, we aim to replicate this approach-aversion effect in Virtual Reality (VR) while fully considering the multimodality of social interaction. Moreover, if the approach-aversion effect is mediated by threat perception, it should be moderated by group membership of the approaching individual. In a first experiment (https://osf.io/yqdwc), we tested our reasoning with Caucasian vs. Maghrebi virtual characters, a group categorization relevant in the French context. We obtained the approach-aversion effect showing that virtual individuals performing an approach movement are perceived more negatively than those who do not perform any movement, F (1,99) = 30.47, p < .0001, PRE = .24, 95% IC [0.66, 1.41]. However, we did not obtain the expected interaction between movement and group membership, F (1,99) = 0.3, p = 0.587, PRE = .003, 95% IC [-0.15, 0.27]. In a second experiment (https://osf.io/dxkvm), we tested our reasoning with Smiling and Frowning virtual characters. Again, we obtained the approach-aversion effect, F (1,131) = 60.16, p < .0001, PRE = .32, 95% IC [0.90, 1.52]. We also obtained an interaction between movement and facial expression opposite to the one we expected with a more important approach-aversion effect for smiling than frowning virtual individuals, F (1,131) = 11.34, p = .001, PRE = .08, 95% IC [0.14, 0.54]. However, results of these first experiments are limited. First, they confounded approach movement and interpersonal space intrusion. Indeed, while static individuals stood at a distance of 85cm from the participants, approaching ones arrived at a distance of 60 cm from them. Such a distance of 60 cm is below the average distance at which people feel comfortable with other (Iachini, Coello, Frassinetti & Ruggiero, 2014). Second, in the second experiment virtual individuals smiled or frowned and then readopted a neutral expression before approaching participants. This may have created an unusual contrast in the smiling condition and eventually explain the unexpected interaction. That’s why, we conducted a third experiment (https://osf.io/yr85f) to disentangle the effect of approach movement and interpersonal space intrusion in the previously obtained approach-aversion effect while testing the threat explanation with slightly smiling vs. frowning faces. To do that, participants encountered approaching and static individuals in two blocks and we moved participants between the block to control the interpersonal distance across condition. In this experiment, the approach-aversion effect was not significant although descriptively in the expected direction, F (1,113) = 0.25, p = .62, PRE = .00, 95% IC [-0.24, 0.40]. Again, we failed to obtain the interaction between movement and facial expression, F (1,113) = 0.65, p = .42, PRE = .00, 95% IC [-0.16, 0.38] but we obtained a three-way interaction between movement, facial expression and block order, F (1,113) = 104.94, p < .001, PRE = .48, 95% IC [-3.35, -2.26]. This interaction suggests that the block structure was probably not appropriate. 
The aim of the present experiment is to test the approach-aversion effect without interpersonal space intrusion. We will also test the threat hypothesis by manipulating if the distance change between the self and the other is initiated by the other or by the participant. Indeed, the approaching movement should be less threatening to participants when they initiate it than when they do not. Thus, we predict that virtual individuals performing an approach movement will be perceived more negatively than those who do not (Hypothesis 1), and that this effect will be moderated by whether participants initiate (not threatening) or virtual individuals initiate the movement (threatening; Hypothesis 2).

question2a.value: When participants initiate virtual individuals' movement, the approaching movement should be less threatening leading to a smaller approach-aversion effect than when participants do not (when virtual individuals initiate the movement).

question3a.value: We will not include manipulation checks in our experiment as it is not necessary (Fayant, Sigall, Lemonnier, Retsin, & Alexopoulos, 2017; Sigall & Mills, 1998).

question1c.value: The relevant variables will be average explicit evaluations, movement of the virtual individuals and initiator of the movement.

question2c.value: We plan to rely on a 2 (Movement: Approach vs. Static) x 2 (Initiator of the movement: Participant vs. Virtual individual) ANOVA with all factors manipulated within-participants.

question3c.value: Virtual individual's movement and initiator of the movement will be the VIs and explicit evaluations the DV. Here, we will be interested in the principal effect of movement on explicit evaluations.

question1c.value: The relevant variables will be average explicit evaluations, movement and initiator of the movement.

question2c.value: We plan to rely on a 2 (Movement: Approach vs. Static) x 2 (Initiator of the movement: Participant vs. Virtual individual) ANOVA with all factors manipulated within-participants.

question3c.value: Virtual individual's movement and initiator of the movement will be the VIs and explicit evaluations the DV. Here, initiator of the movement will be the moderator of the effect of movement on explicit evaluations.

Second, in the second experiment virtual individuals smiled or frowned and then readopted a neutral expression before approaching participants. This may have created an unusual contrast in the smiling condition and eventually explain the unexpected interaction. That’s why, we conducted a third experiment (https://osf.io/yr85f) to disentangle the effect of approach movement and interpersonal space intrusion in the previously obtained approach-aversion effect while testing the threat explanation with slightly smiling vs. frowning faces. To do that, participants encountered approaching and static individuals in two blocks and we moved participants between the block to control the interpersonal distance across condition. In this experiment, the approach-aversion effect was not significant although descriptively in the expected direction, F (1,113) = 0.25, p = .62, PRE = .00, 95% IC [-0.24, 0.40]. Again, we failed to obtain the interaction between movement and facial expression, F (1,113) = 0.65, p = .42, PRE = .00, 95% IC [-0.16, 0.38] but we obtained a three-way interaction between movement, facial expression and block order, F (1,113) = 104.94, p < .001, PRE = .48, 95% IC [-3.35, -2.26]. This interaction suggests that the block structure was probably not appropriate. 
The aim of the present experiment is to test the approach-aversion effect without interpersonal space intrusion. We will also test the threat hypothesis by manipulating if the distance change between the self and the other is initiated by the other or by the participant. Indeed, the approaching movement should be less threatening to participants when they initiate it than when they do not. Thus, we predict that virtual individuals performing an approach movement will be perceived more negatively than those who do not (Hypothesis 1), and that this effect will be moderated by whether participants initiate (not threatening) or virtual individuals initiate the movement (threatening; Hypothesis 2).
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question2a: When participants initiate virtual individuals' movement, the approaching movement should be less threatening leading to a smaller approach-aversion effect than when participants do not (when virtual individuals initiate the movement).
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question3a: We will not include manipulation checks in our experiment as it is not necessary (Fayant, Sigall, Lemonnier, Retsin, & Alexopoulos, 2017; Sigall & Mills, 1998).
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2a:
a-	IV1: Movement (Approach vs. Static) – Within-participants variable. This variable will be operationalized through one step forward vs. no step of the virtual agent.
IV2: Threatening nature of the virtual character (Threatening vs. Not threatening). – Within-participants variable. This variable will be operationalized through the fact that participants initiate virtual individuals' movement (not threatening) or not (threatening).
b-	N/A
registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10: Participants will first sign a consent form. As a cover story, we will explain to them that we are developing a Virtual Reality (VR) application in which users can interact with others via their avatar. We will inform them that in the study they are taking part, we test if our application is able to reflect the impression that individuals give in real life. Thus, we will make them believe, that the virtual individuals they encounter are the avatars of real people and that they will have to give their global impression about each one of them. We also pretexted that at the same time we tested the sound detection sensitivity of our device and that they will have to indicate to some individuals where they have to position themselves by saying “Come here” or “Stay there”. Then, participants will be immersed in VR. Participants will put the VR headset with the experimenter’s assistance to enter the Immersive Virtual Reality Environment (IVRE). First, participants will familiarize with the VR in the bus stop and hear the instructions through headphones. Then, two training virtual individual will come in front of them (one for asking to come and one for asking to stay there), followed by the 16 critical ones (two men and two women in each of the four conditions). Half of virtual individuals will perform an approach movement toward participants once in front of them (approximately one step, finishing at 85 cm from participants) while the other half will stay on spot (at a distance of 110 cm from participants). For half virtual individuals in each movement condition, participants will have to request them to come (after a sound signal) and for the other half they will have to request them to stay there (after a different sound signal). For each individual, a Likert-type scale will appear in the virtual environment and participants will use the controllers to provide their impression toward him/her anchored at 1 (very negative) and 7 (very positive). For each participant, the order of trials as well as virtual individuals’ repartition within the four conditions will be randomly generated with R before the session. After performing the VR task, participants will complete the Presence questionnaire of Makransky, Lilleholt and Aaby (2017). At the end of this questionnaire, we will present some additional items. Participants will indicate any sickness symptoms (i.e., oculomotor troubles, disorientation and/or nausea due to the VR; 0 “Not at all”/1 “Slightly”/ 2 “A lot”/ 3 “Severely”) and report alcohol or illicit substance intake. We will ask participant their age, the gender they identify with and if they are fluent in French. Finally, participants will be probed for suspicion about the aim of the study and debriefed.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi: The relevant variables will be average explicit evaluations, movement of the virtual individuals and initiator of the movement.
We plan to rely on a 2 (Movement: Approach vs. Static) x 2 (Initiator of the movement: Participant vs. Virtual individual) ANOVA with all factors manipulated within-participants.
Virtual individual's movement and initiator of the movement will be the VIs and explicit evaluations the DV. Here, we will be interested in the principal effect of movement on explicit evaluations.
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: All the data will be collected in four experimental boxes at the Psychological Institute of Université de Paris in Boulogne-Billancourt (92100, FRANCE). Participants will be recruited on a voluntary basis, in exchange of a 5€ honorarium or credit course. All experimenters will be trained and will follow the same script.

Regarding the sample size, we plan to run at minimum 200 participants. Such a criterion enables us to detect an effect size η² of .004 with a power of 80%. Anticipating some data exclusions, we plan to collect data from approximately 220 participants.
We will stop registration to participate in the experiment when the 220 criterion is met.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-second.second.ques: The relevant variables will be average explicit evaluations, movement and initiator of the movement.
We plan to rely on a 2 (Movement: Approach vs. Static) x 2 (Initiator of the movement: Participant vs. Virtual individual) ANOVA with all factors manipulated within-participants.

Virtual individual's movement and initiator of the movement will be the VIs and explicit evaluations the DV. Here, initiator of the movement will be the moderator of the effect of movement on explicit evaluations.
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q: a- We will exclude trials in the Virtual Reality task for which participants deviate from the instructed position (staying on spot). Moreover, a participant with more than 20% of this type of trials will be excluded from analysis. We will also exclude trials for which participants give an instruction to the virtual individuals when it is not required. b- We will exclude participants if they guess our hypothesis and/or express suspicion concerning the link between the movement and evaluation. c- We will exclude participants who are not fluent in French d- We will also exclude participants that indicate a “severe” sickness due to the VR or report alcohol or illicit substances consumption.

attributes.title: Cancel the deal? How do Americans respond to the exploitation of customers?
attributes.description: A growing literature in economics has identified the opportunity for companies to generate profit from exploiting predictable mistakes of consumers. In this project, we are investigating if this firm behavior is considered as unfair by impartial observers.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value:
Cancel the deal? How do Americans respond to the exploitation of customers? 

In this project we investigate the willingness of Americans to cancel a deal that they might perceive as unfair.

other.value: To implement the decisions of the third-parties, we will run an additional experiment with buyers and sellers on an international online labor market. In that experiment, we will measure the share of sellers who are willing to profit of the mistake of buyers. We will again test if that share varies with the involvement of the seller in that situation. We also ran an mTurk pilot in which we measured the shares of third-parties that intervened into the exchange. We only did the pilot for two of the four treatments. We did that to get a better idea of effect sizes. We will report the outcomes of that mTurk pilot in the paper. For exploratory data analysis, we also measure participants' certainty about their decision. We will see if treatment variation changed participants' certainty in their decisions.

sample.value: We will collect a total of 4000 participants. We will randomize them into treatment conditions at an equal number, leaving 1000 participants for every treatment. That will give us sufficient power to detect an effect of 0.15 SD at 90% power based on a Monte-Carlo simulation performed in State 16.0SE

analyses.value: We will run OLS-regressions with robust standard errors to see how the willingness of third-parties to intervene into the transaction varies based on different levels of involvement of the seller. For that purpose, we test a linear probability model with dummy variables for which treatment the third-party is randomly assigned to We will run the regression with and without control variables. Controls include demographics and political orientation. We will run these regressions for the two different dependent variables. Moreover, we test for heterogeneity of the treatment effect based on demographics and political affiliation. We also measure general policy preferences with regards to stricter legislation regarding firms. To measure external validity, we will see if these measures correlate with the participants' decisions in the main experiment.

outliers.value: We will screen out participants who fail an attention check and who answer the main treatment question in below 35 seconds. These are not included in the final sample.

dependent.value: We are measuring two main dependent variables. For that purpose, we present third-parties with a description of an exchange of a product between a buyer and a seller. Third-parties are then given a binary choice to either cancel the transaction or not. If they decide to cancel, they have another choice of whether to punish the seller with a fine. Our first dependent variable is the share of participants cancelling the deal (DV: Cancel / All participants) Our second dependent variable is the share of third-parties who assign a fine to the seller. (DV: Fine / All participants). This share is a combination of the share cancelling the deal and the share among those cancelling the deal that punishes the seller.

conditions.value: We are randomly assigning third-parties participants to one of four different conditions, where the conditions randomly vary in terms of the level of involvement that the seller had in the transaction. Random assignment will be done using the mechanism of Qualtrics' survey engine.

hypothesis.value:
A growing literature in economics has identified the opportunity for companies to generate profit from exploiting predictable mistakes of consumers. In this project, we are investigating if this firm behavior is considered as unfair by impartial observers. We are measuring the extent to which third-parties are willing to cancel a transaction between a seller and a buyer when the seller makes an additional profit of a mistake made by the buyer. We are investigating the causal impact how the seller’s involvement in the trade affects participants’ decision to cancel the deal. This enables us to identify three distinct types of participants. We are testing the following hypotheses: 

H1: A substantial share of people always intervenes in transactions in which the seller makes a profit from a buyer's misunderstanding of the value of a product ("Substantialists") 

H2: A substantial share of people never intervenes in transactions in which the seller makes a profit from a buyer's misunderstanding of the value of a product ("Contractualists") 

H3: A significant share of people will make their decision to intervene dependend on the behavior of the seller ("Proceduralists")
