attributes.title: Perception of COVID-19 in the American Public
attributes.description: The purpose of this study is to investigate the relationship between threat perception and preferences for various governmental responses related to the COVID-19 pandemic.  This project addresses two related research questions. First, do Americans vary in their assessment of the kinds of threats posed by COVID-19? And, if so, does that variation help explain differential support for certain federal, state, and local policies?  These policies include social-distancing restrictions, prioritizing lives saved over near-term economic impacts, and directing government funding towards businesses, health care, or individuals?  At a time when these policies are being debated and the stakes are high, some sense of the correlations between perception and preferences could help inform public discussion.

q2.value:
There are three families of hypotheses.  The first concerns the relationship between the relevance of particular kinds of threat and specific emotions and policy preferences.
1.	The more relevant the threat of physical harm is, relative to the threat of loss (measured as a difference score), the more likely a respondent is to:
a.	Report feeling fear
b.	Report practicing social distancing
c.	Prefer government policies protecting citizens’ health over the economy
d.	Support equipping hospitals rather than transferring cash to citizens or businesses
2.	The more relevant the threat of loss is, relative to the threat of physical harm, the more likely a respondent is to:
a.	Report feeling anger
b.	Prefer the government protect the economy
c.	Support cash transfers over hospital equipment purchases
The second set of hypotheses concerns the relationship between geographic proximity to outbreaks and the other variables:
3.	The severity of the outbreak in the respondent’s county will be positively correlated with:
a.	The absolute perception of physical harm to oneself
b.	The relative importance of physical harm versus loss
c.	Feelings of fear, but not anger
d.	Reported practicing social distancing
e.	Preferring government policies protecting citizens’ health over the economy
f.	Supporting equipping hospitals rather than transferring cash to citizens or businesses
4.	After controlling for the effect of partisanship, gender, and age, geographic proximity will still have a statistically significant relationship with absolute and relative measures of threat perception and policy preferences
The third set of hypotheses concerns the relationship between political partisanship and the other variables:
5.	Republicans will be more likely to:
a.	Perceive COVID-19 as posing a relatively greater threat of loss than of physical harm
b.	Report feeling anger, rather than fear
c.	Support government policies protecting the economy over public health
6.	Democrats will be more likely to:
a.	Perceive COVID-19 as posing a relatively greater threat of physical harm than of loss
b.	Report feeling fear, rather than anger
c.	Support government policies protecting public health over the economy

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Observational study of a nationally representative online sample of Americans.  Question block ordering will be counterbalanced across participants.  Questions within blocks will be randomized.  Response options within questions will be randomized, with some exceptions.

q7.value: There is no between-subject randomization involved, other than question order presentation for the purpose of counterbalancing.  There is no experimental treatment.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: This study aims to collect responses from a nationally representative sample of adults.  All participants will be located in the United States.  Subjects will be recruited via the online service Lucid Marketplace, which matches participants to studies based on targeting criteria such as demographic composition.   Researchers pay Lucid $1 per completed survey.  Researchers cannot control how much participants receive in direct compensation.  Subjects must be 18 or older to participate.  There is no age cut-off.  Because of the desired composition of the sample, demographic characteristics will exclude some potential participants.  However, once a subject begins the study, there are no exclusion criteria for payment other than speeding or straight-lining.  Complete responses will only be included in the final analyses if subjects meet the criteria for inclusion (see Analysis Plan).  Data collection will begin no later than April 10, 2020 and completed as quickly as possible.

q11.value: The target usable sample is 2,100 responses  I expect approximately 20% of responses to be unusable due to incomplete answers or failed attention checks.  Based on this target, the total planned maximum number of participants is 2,500.

q12.value: Because this issue is rapidly shifting, it is important to collect responses in a relatively narrow window so larger is not necessarily better in this case.  2,100 individuals is not as large as many professional nat rep surveys, but greater than the minimum offered by services such as Qualtrics.

question.value:
The survey directly measures the following demographic variables:
-	age: numeric
-	gender: factor (male, female)
-	education: factor (8 levels) corresponding to degrees attained
-	hhi: factor (25 levels) corresponding to tiers of household income
-	ethnicity: factor (16 levels)
-	hispanic: factor (15 levels)
-	party_id: factor (10 levels); the subset of items corresponding to conventional party designations (Democrat, Republican, and Independent) will be treated as a 7-point continuous scale; those indicating Other (3 options) will be dropped from any analysis of party affiliation
-	region: factor (4 levels) corresponding to four broad geographic regions
-	zip_1: zip code provided by Lucid as external data
-	zip_2: zip code provided voluntarily by participant

The survey directly measures the following variables of interest:
-	sd_practice: a binary measure of whether the respondent is currently practicing social distancing
-	sd_order: a binary measure of whether the respondent is currently under a stay-at-home or shelter-in-place order
-	danger_cov19: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating the perceived dangerousness of COVID-19
-	danger_cch: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating the perceived dangerousness of climate change
-	danger_imm: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating the perceived dangerousness of immigration
-	danger_nwar: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating the perceived dangerousness of nuclear war
-	harm_self: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating the relevance of the possibility that COVID-19 could cause physical harm, including death, to the respondent
-	harm_others: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating the relevance of the possibility that COVID-19 could cause physical harm, including death, to the respondent’s loved ones
-	loss_asset: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating the relevance of the possibility that COVID-19 could cause the respondent to lose a material asset, including their job or house
-	loss_rights: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating the relevance of the possibility that COVID-19 could cause the respondent to lose a non-material asset, including their rights or freedoms
-	cont_env: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating the relevance of the possibility that COVID-19 could cause the respondent’s physical environment to be contaminated, including spaces and surfaces
-	emo_fear: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating how much fear the respondent feels when thinking about COVID-19
-	emo_anger: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating how much anger the respondent feels when thinking about COVID-19
-	emo_disgust: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating how much disgust the respondent feels when thinking about COVID-19
-	emo_pity: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating how much pity the respondent feels when thinking about COVID-19
-	emo_happy: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating how much happiness the respondent feels when thinking about COVID-19
-	emo_sad: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating how much sadness the respondent feels when thinking about COVID-19
-	dur_sd: an ordinal factor indicating how long the federal government should encourage Americans to practice social distancing (months, weeks, not at all), along with a Don’t Know option
-	trade_health: a five-point Likert item (Strongly Disagree – Strongly Agree) indicating agreement that the government should protect the health of citizens, even if it hurts the economy, along with a DK option
-	trade_econ: a five-point Likert item (Strongly Disagree – Strongly Agree) indicating agreement that the government should protect the economy, even if it means more fatalities due to COVID-19, along with a DK option
-	zero_sum: a factor (4 levels) for whom to support if the government could pick only one target of aid (large business, small business, cash to citizens, medical equipment), along with None of the Above and DK

I will also collect variables reflecting the local COVID-19 outbreak based on zip code information.  County-level data will be sourced from USAfacts.org on the day after the survey closes.  USAfacts.org collects daily measures of COVID-19 cases at the county level.  Zip codes will be mapped to County FIPS codes.  Measures for a respondent will correspond to the data for the day before their survey completion date.
-	local_cases: a continuous numeric variable of the number confirmed cases in the respondent’s county
-	local_deaths: a continuous numeric variable of the number confirmed cases in the respondent’s county
-	local_cases_pc: a continuous numeric variable of the number confirmed cases in the respondent’s county divided by the total county population (also taken from USAfacts.org)
-	local_deaths_pc: a continuous numeric variable of the number confirmed deaths in the respondent’s county divided by the total county population (also taken from USAfacts.org)
-	double_cases: a continuous numeric variable for the number of days it took to double the case count, using the local_cases value for T=1 
-	double_deaths: a continuous numeric variable for the number of days it took to double the death count, using the local_cases value for T=1

Two summary measures will be used for the threat perception measures.  A summary physical harm (harm_max) score will be generated by taking the maximum of the scores for self and loved-ones.  A summary loss score (loss_max) will be generated by taking the maximum of the asset and rights scores.

A difference score (net_harm) will be used to measure the extent to which individuals are more concerned about their physical safety than the loss of material or non-material assets. This score will take the difference between the harm_max and loss_max.  It will range from 100 to -100.

I will also create a tradeoff score based on subtracting the trade_health from trade_econ.  This approach treats the Likert items as numeric, with equidistant values, which is an assumption of convenience.  The resulting score will range from 6 to -6.

Several types of models will be used.  The empty models specified here may be substituted with correlation tables.  Note that H4 is satisfied by the model specifications listed.

Hypotheses 1a, 1c, 2a-b, 3a-c, 3e
-	Linear regression with and without control variables (gender, age, party_id)

Hypotheses 1b, 3d
-	Logistic regression with and without control variables (gender, age, party_id)

Hypotheses 1d, 2c, 3f 
-	Multinomial logistic regression with and without control variables (gender, age, party_id)

Hypotheses 5a-c, 6a-c
-	T-test (two-sided) for the difference in means
-	K-S test for the difference in densities

q18.value:
I plan to create binary versions of the five threat perception measures and the two summary measures (harm, loss).  These binary measures will code any value on the continuous scale less than 20 as a 0 and greater than 20 as a 1.  This cut-point is based on prior research and is intended to divide the sample for whom a threat is irrelevant from those for whom it is at least minimally relevant.  I will take the same approach with the emotions responses, generating binary responses based on the 20 / 100 cut-point.

Many of the demographic measures will be consolidated.  The education measure will be reduced into a smaller number of levels (No college degree, Associates, Bachelors, Advanced, none of the above).  The household income measure will also be reduced to five categories.  The ethnicity measure will be reduced to for the categories Asian (7 options) and Pacific Islander (4 options). 

The continuous variables (threat perception, emotion, dangerousness, and their indices) will be rescaled to (0-10) to make regression coefficients easier to interpret.

q19.value: For both the correlational and multiple regression analyses, the criteria used will be p-values (threshold of 0.05).  All hypotheses are intended as independent tests, with the exception of testing several measures of outbreak severity.  Where two measures are tested (cases and deaths, for example), the distribution of the parameters of interest will be determined via permutation and inference based on the results.

q20.value:
Several criteria will be used to drop complete observations prior to analyses:

Attention Check
At the start of the survey participants receive a warning that there will be questions that assess whether they are reading the instructions.  80% of the way through the survey, there is an attention check question.  Responses will only be dropped for those who fail the attention check and also complete the survey in the fastest quintile.  This joint requirement increases the likelihood that failed checks are the result of speeding rather than reading comprehension or ordinary lapses in concentration.
 
Straight-lining Emotion Questions
Lucid allows researchers to contest responses that show no deviation in the values selected.  In practice, this is hard to detect, since I have randomized the presentation of answers.  However, participants who straightline in the emotion section will be dropped.  The justification is that it is highly unlikely for a participant to feel equally afraid, happy, sad, disgusted, and angry. 

Zip Code Matching
Lucid requests participant zip code information in order to meet the region requirement of the representativeness of the sample (variable zip_1).  I also ask participants for their zip code (zip_2).  If these values do not match, I will exclude the response from all analyses.  If the values for zip_1 and zip_2 differ by a single digit (i.e., appear to be a typo), the respondent will be retained for all analyses other than the geographic ones.  For geographic analyses, they will be dropped only if the typo affects their county assignment.

q21.value: All questions require a response other than the zip code question.  Those who refuse to provide zip_2 will be dropped from any geographic analyses, but not from any other analyses unless they qualify as excluded data.

q22.value: The primary exploratory analyses concern the similarity between Republicans who live in high-outbreak areas, Republicans who live in areas less currently affected, and Democrats.  Two types of analyses will be used to explore similarity in threat perception and in emotional responses.  Threat perception will be looked at in 3-dimensional space (physical harm, loss, contamination) and 5-dimensional space (all 5 measures).  The 5-dimensional space analysis will construct similarity matrices between the three groups (using both a correlational measure and Euclidean distance).  The 3-dimensional space measure will use hypervolumes (nonparametric shells which can include holes) and nearest-edge distances to compare the group of interest (Republican/high outbreak) to volumes constructed for Republicans/low outbreak and Democrats.  The emotions analyses will be similar, using a 3-dimensional version (fear, anger, disgust) and a 6-dimensional version (all available emotions).

q23.value: This research is part of a larger program on the relationship between threat perception and policy preferences

q4: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q7: There is no between-subject randomization involved, other than question order presentation for the purpose of counterbalancing.  There is no experimental treatment.
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q11: The target usable sample is 2,100 responses  I expect approximately 20% of responses to be unusable due to incomplete answers or failed attention checks.  Based on this target, the total planned maximum number of participants is 2,500.
registration_responses.q12: Because this issue is rapidly shifting, it is important to collect responses in a relatively narrow window so larger is not necessarily better in this case.  2,100 individuals is not as large as many professional nat rep surveys, but greater than the minimum offered by services such as Qualtrics.
registration_responses.q18:
I plan to create binary versions of the five threat perception measures and the two summary measures (harm, loss).  These binary measures will code any value on the continuous scale less than 20 as a 0 and greater than 20 as a 1.  This cut-point is based on prior research and is intended to divide the sample for whom a threat is irrelevant from those for whom it is at least minimally relevant.  I will take the same approach with the emotions responses, generating binary responses based on the 20 / 100 cut-point.

Many of the demographic measures will be consolidated.  The education measure will be reduced into a smaller number of levels (No college degree, Associates, Bachelors, Advanced, none of the above).  The household income measure will also be reduced to five categories.  The ethnicity measure will be reduced to for the categories Asian (7 options) and Pacific Islander (4 options). 

The continuous variables (threat perception, emotion, dangerousness, and their indices) will be rescaled to (0-10) to make regression coefficients easier to interpret.
registration_responses.q19: For both the correlational and multiple regression analyses, the criteria used will be p-values (threshold of 0.05).  All hypotheses are intended as independent tests, with the exception of testing several measures of outbreak severity.  Where two measures are tested (cases and deaths, for example), the distribution of the parameters of interest will be determined via permutation and inference based on the results.
registration_responses.q20:
Several criteria will be used to drop complete observations prior to analyses:

Attention Check
At the start of the survey participants receive a warning that there will be questions that assess whether they are reading the instructions.  80% of the way through the survey, there is an attention check question.  Responses will only be dropped for those who fail the attention check and also complete the survey in the fastest quintile.  This joint requirement increases the likelihood that failed checks are the result of speeding rather than reading comprehension or ordinary lapses in concentration.
 
Straight-lining Emotion Questions
Lucid allows researchers to contest responses that show no deviation in the values selected.  In practice, this is hard to detect, since I have randomized the presentation of answers.  However, participants who straightline in the emotion section will be dropped.  The justification is that it is highly unlikely for a participant to feel equally afraid, happy, sad, disgusted, and angry. 

Zip Code Matching
Lucid requests participant zip code information in order to meet the region requirement of the representativeness of the sample (variable zip_1).  I also ask participants for their zip code (zip_2).  If these values do not match, I will exclude the response from all analyses.  If the values for zip_1 and zip_2 differ by a single digit (i.e., appear to be a typo), the respondent will be retained for all analyses other than the geographic ones.  For geographic analyses, they will be dropped only if the typo affects their county assignment.
registration_responses.q21: All questions require a response other than the zip code question.  Those who refuse to provide zip_2 will be dropped from any geographic analyses, but not from any other analyses unless they qualify as excluded data.
registration_responses.q22: The primary exploratory analyses concern the similarity between Republicans who live in high-outbreak areas, Republicans who live in areas less currently affected, and Democrats.  Two types of analyses will be used to explore similarity in threat perception and in emotional responses.  Threat perception will be looked at in 3-dimensional space (physical harm, loss, contamination) and 5-dimensional space (all 5 measures).  The 5-dimensional space analysis will construct similarity matrices between the three groups (using both a correlational measure and Euclidean distance).  The 3-dimensional space measure will use hypervolumes (nonparametric shells which can include holes) and nearest-edge distances to compare the group of interest (Republican/high outbreak) to volumes constructed for Republicans/low outbreak and Democrats.  The emotions analyses will be similar, using a 3-dimensional version (fear, anger, disgust) and a 6-dimensional version (all available emotions).
registration_responses.q23: This research is part of a larger program on the relationship between threat perception and policy preferences
registration_responses.q6.question: Observational study of a nationally representative online sample of Americans.  Question block ordering will be counterbalanced across participants.  Questions within blocks will be randomized.  Response options within questions will be randomized, with some exceptions.
registration_responses.q10.question: This study aims to collect responses from a nationally representative sample of adults.  All participants will be located in the United States.  Subjects will be recruited via the online service Lucid Marketplace, which matches participants to studies based on targeting criteria such as demographic composition.   Researchers pay Lucid $1 per completed survey.  Researchers cannot control how much participants receive in direct compensation.  Subjects must be 18 or older to participate.  There is no age cut-off.  Because of the desired composition of the sample, demographic characteristics will exclude some potential participants.  However, once a subject begins the study, there are no exclusion criteria for payment other than speeding or straight-lining.  Complete responses will only be included in the final analyses if subjects meet the criteria for inclusion (see Analysis Plan).  Data collection will begin no later than April 10, 2020 and completed as quickly as possible.
registration_responses.q14.question: N/A (observational study)
registration_responses.q15.question:
The survey directly measures the following demographic variables:
-	age: numeric
-	gender: factor (male, female)
-	education: factor (8 levels) corresponding to degrees attained
-	hhi: factor (25 levels) corresponding to tiers of household income
-	ethnicity: factor (16 levels)
-	hispanic: factor (15 levels)
-	party_id: factor (10 levels); the subset of items corresponding to conventional party designations (Democrat, Republican, and Independent) will be treated as a 7-point continuous scale; those indicating Other (3 options) will be dropped from any analysis of party affiliation
-	region: factor (4 levels) corresponding to four broad geographic regions
-	zip_1: zip code provided by Lucid as external data
-	zip_2: zip code provided voluntarily by participant

The survey directly measures the following variables of interest:
-	sd_practice: a binary measure of whether the respondent is currently practicing social distancing
-	sd_order: a binary measure of whether the respondent is currently under a stay-at-home or shelter-in-place order
-	danger_cov19: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating the perceived dangerousness of COVID-19
-	danger_cch: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating the perceived dangerousness of climate change
-	danger_imm: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating the perceived dangerousness of immigration
-	danger_nwar: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating the perceived dangerousness of nuclear war
-	harm_self: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating the relevance of the possibility that COVID-19 could cause physical harm, including death, to the respondent
-	harm_others: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating the relevance of the possibility that COVID-19 could cause physical harm, including death, to the respondent’s loved ones
-	loss_asset: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating the relevance of the possibility that COVID-19 could cause the respondent to lose a material asset, including their job or house
-	loss_rights: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating the relevance of the possibility that COVID-19 could cause the respondent to lose a non-material asset, including their rights or freedoms
-	cont_env: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating the relevance of the possibility that COVID-19 could cause the respondent’s physical environment to be contaminated, including spaces and surfaces
-	emo_fear: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating how much fear the respondent feels when thinking about COVID-19
-	emo_anger: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating how much anger the respondent feels when thinking about COVID-19
-	emo_disgust: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating how much disgust the respondent feels when thinking about COVID-19
-	emo_pity: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating how much pity the respondent feels when thinking about COVID-19
-	emo_happy: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating how much happiness the respondent feels when thinking about COVID-19
-	emo_sad: a numeric variable (0,100) indicating how much sadness the respondent feels when thinking about COVID-19
-	dur_sd: an ordinal factor indicating how long the federal government should encourage Americans to practice social distancing (months, weeks, not at all), along with a Don’t Know option
-	trade_health: a five-point Likert item (Strongly Disagree – Strongly Agree) indicating agreement that the government should protect the health of citizens, even if it hurts the economy, along with a DK option
-	trade_econ: a five-point Likert item (Strongly Disagree – Strongly Agree) indicating agreement that the government should protect the economy, even if it means more fatalities due to COVID-19, along with a DK option
-	zero_sum: a factor (4 levels) for whom to support if the government could pick only one target of aid (large business, small business, cash to citizens, medical equipment), along with None of the Above and DK

I will also collect variables reflecting the local COVID-19 outbreak based on zip code information.  County-level data will be sourced from USAfacts.org on the day after the survey closes.  USAfacts.org collects daily measures of COVID-19 cases at the county level.  Zip codes will be mapped to County FIPS codes.  Measures for a respondent will correspond to the data for the day before their survey completion date.
-	local_cases: a continuous numeric variable of the number confirmed cases in the respondent’s county
-	local_deaths: a continuous numeric variable of the number confirmed cases in the respondent’s county
-	local_cases_pc: a continuous numeric variable of the number confirmed cases in the respondent’s county divided by the total county population (also taken from USAfacts.org)
-	local_deaths_pc: a continuous numeric variable of the number confirmed deaths in the respondent’s county divided by the total county population (also taken from USAfacts.org)
-	double_cases: a continuous numeric variable for the number of days it took to double the case count, using the local_cases value for T=1 
-	double_deaths: a continuous numeric variable for the number of days it took to double the death count, using the local_cases value for T=1
registration_responses.q16.question:
Two summary measures will be used for the threat perception measures.  A summary physical harm (harm_max) score will be generated by taking the maximum of the scores for self and loved-ones.  A summary loss score (loss_max) will be generated by taking the maximum of the asset and rights scores.

A difference score (net_harm) will be used to measure the extent to which individuals are more concerned about their physical safety than the loss of material or non-material assets. This score will take the difference between the harm_max and loss_max.  It will range from 100 to -100.

I will also create a tradeoff score based on subtracting the trade_health from trade_econ.  This approach treats the Likert items as numeric, with equidistant values, which is an assumption of convenience.  The resulting score will range from 6 to -6.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Several types of models will be used.  The empty models specified here may be substituted with correlation tables.  Note that H4 is satisfied by the model specifications listed.

Hypotheses 1a, 1c, 2a-b, 3a-c, 3e
-	Linear regression with and without control variables (gender, age, party_id)

Hypotheses 1b, 3d
-	Logistic regression with and without control variables (gender, age, party_id)

Hypotheses 1d, 2c, 3f 
-	Multinomial logistic regression with and without control variables (gender, age, party_id)

Hypotheses 5a-c, 6a-c
-	T-test (two-sided) for the difference in means
-	K-S test for the difference in densities
